commit_message:
Update source-branch-updater to work with IRR's

This updated the sources-branch-updater convenience script which
is used to update SHA's and ensure that all carried files are
appropriately included in the update.

The patch includes the following changes:

 - Automatically submit updates of applicable files to all the
   independent repositories.

 - Automatically update the ansible-role-requirements.yml file
   with the latest SHA from the independent repositories or the
   latest tag from any repositories that are not part of OSA.
   This functionality is disabled by design for the master branch.

 - Adds ansible-role-requirements-editor.py which provides the
   ability to edit the ansible-role-requirements.yml file
   appropriately and output a consistent result.

Conflicts:
 - ansible-role-requirements.yml

Backport note:
 - This patch also includes the subsequent update of the script
   from Idde0141691e1008bead802bd6f3759c12e37b02b

Change-Id: I67fadeb43cc65a557d0380a12eb3e94335097d0d
(cherry picked from commit fac50305715d23b07626cf0ce551b531128ac34e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/16/306016/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OS_BRANCH=${OS_BRANCH:-"master"} OSA_BRANCH=${OSA_BRANCH:-"$OS_BRANCH"} -b|--openstack-branch (name of OpenStack branch, eg: stable/mitaka) -o|--osa-branch (name of the OSA branch, eg: stable/mitaka) -s|--service-file (path to service file to parse) -b|--openstack-branch) OS_BRANCH="$2" shift ;; -o|--osa-branch) OSA_BRANCH="$2" branch_data=$(git ls-remote ${repo_address} | grep "${OS_BRANCH}$") branch_entry="${branch_sha} # HEAD of \"$OS_BRANCH\" as of $(date +%d.%m.%Y)" os_repo_tmp_path="/tmp/os_${repo_name}" osa_repo_tmp_path="/tmp/osa_${repo_name}" # Ensure that the temp path doesn't exist rm -rf ${os_repo_tmp_path} ${osa_repo_tmp_path} # Do a shallow clone of the OpenStack repo to work with git clone --quiet --depth=10 --branch ${OS_BRANCH} --no-checkout --single-branch ${repo_address} ${os_repo_tmp_path} pushd ${os_repo_tmp_path} > /dev/null git checkout --quiet ${branch_sha} popd > /dev/null # Set the OSA address if [[ "${repo_name}" == "ironic" ]]; then osa_repo_address="https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-ironic" else osa_repo_address="https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_${repo_name}" # Do a shallow clone of the OSA repo to work with git clone --quiet --depth=10 --branch ${OSA_BRANCH} --single-branch ${osa_repo_address} ${osa_repo_tmp_path} pushd ${osa_repo_tmp_path} > /dev/null git checkout --quiet origin/${OSA_BRANCH} popd > /dev/null # Update the policy files find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "policy.json" -exec \ cp {} "${osa_repo_tmp_path}/templates/policy.json.j2" \; # Tweak the paste files find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*[_-]paste.ini" -exec \ sed -i.bak "s|hmac_keys = SECRET_KEY|hmac_keys = {{ ${repo_name}_profiler_hmac_key }}|" {} \; # Update the paste files find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*[_-]paste.ini" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${osa_repo_tmp_path}/templates/\$(basename \${name}).j2\"" \; # Tweak the rootwrap conf files find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "rootwrap.conf" -exec \ sed -i.bak "s|exec_dirs=|exec_dirs={{ ${repo_name}_bin }},|" {} \; # Update the rootwrap conf files find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "rootwrap.conf" -exec \ cp {} "${osa_repo_tmp_path}/templates/rootwrap.conf.j2" \; # Update the rootwrap filters find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*.filters" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${osa_repo_tmp_path}/files/rootwrap.d/\$(basename \${name})\"" \; # Update the yaml files for Ceilometer if [ "${repo_name}" = "ceilometer" ]; then find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*.yaml" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${osa_repo_tmp_path}/templates/\$(basename \${name}).j2\"" \; fi # Update the yaml files for Heat if [ "${repo_name}" = "heat" ]; then find ${os_repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*.yaml" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${osa_repo_tmp_path}/templates/\$(echo \${name} | rev | cut -sd / -f -2 | rev).j2\"" \; fi # Switch into the OSA git directory to work with it pushd ${osa_repo_tmp_path} > /dev/null # Check for changed files git_changed=$(git status --porcelain | wc -l) # Check for untracked files git_untracked=$(git ls-files --other --exclude-standard --directory | wc -l) if [ ${git_untracked} -gt 0 ]; then # If there are untracked files, ensure that the commit message includes # a WIP prefix so that the patch is revised in more detail. git_msg_prefix="[New files - needs update] " else git_msg_prefix="" fi # If any files have changed, submit a patch including the changes if [ ${git_changed} -gt 0 ]; then git review -s > /dev/null git add --all git commit -a -m "${git_msg_prefix}Update paste, policy and rootwrap configurations $(date +%Y-%m-%d)" --quiet git review > /dev/null fi popd > /dev/null # Clean up the temporary files rm -rf ${os_repo_tmp_path} ${osa_repo_tmp_path}# Update the PIP_INSTALL_OPTIONS with the current versions of pip, wheel and setuptools # Update the ansible-role-requirements.yml file # We don't want to be doing this for the master branch if [[ "${OSA_BRANCH}" != "master" ]]; then echo "Updating ansible-role-requirements.yml" # Loop through each of the role git sources for role_src in $(awk '/src: / {print $2}' ansible-role-requirements.yml); do # Determine the role's name role_name=$(sed 's/^[ \t-]*//' ansible-role-requirements.yml | awk '/src: / || /name: / {print $2}' | grep -B1 "${role_src}" | head -n 1) # Grab the latest SHA that matches the specified branch role_version=$(git ls-remote ${role_src} | grep "${OSA_BRANCH}$" | awk '{print $1}') # If that branch doesn't exist, then it's probably not an OpenStack-Ansible role, so grab the latest tag instead if [[ -z "${role_version}" ]]; then role_version=$(git ls-remote --tags ${role_src} | awk '{print $2}' | grep -v '{}' | cut -d/ -f 3 | sort -n | tail -n 1) fi # Now use the information we have to update the ansible-role-requirements file $(dirname ${0})/ansible-role-requirements-editer.py -f ansible-role-requirements.yml -n "${role_name}" -v "${role_version}" done echo "Completed updating ansible-role-requirements.yml" else echo "Skipping the ansible-role-requirements.yml update as we're working on the master branch" fi
deleted_lines: ONLINE_BRANCH=${ONLINE_BRANCH:-"master"}OSA_ROLE_PATH="${OSA_ROLE_PATH:-playbooks/roles}" OSA_ROLE_PREFIX="${OSA_ROLE_PREFIX:-os}" OSA_ROLE_LOCAL="${OSA_ROLE_PATH}/${OSA_ROLE_PREFIX}" -b|--branch (name of branch, eg: stable/liberty) -s|--service-file (path to service yaml file to parse) -r|--osa-role-path (path to stored roles to update, eg: 'playbooks/roles') -p|--osa-role-prefix (the prefix in front of OpenStack service roles, eg: 'os') -b|--branch) ONLINE_BRANCH="$2" -r|--osa-role-path) OSA_ROLE_PATH="$2" shift ;; -p|--osa-role-prefix) OSA_ROLE_PREFIX="$2" shift ;; branch_data=$(git ls-remote ${repo_address} | grep "${ONLINE_BRANCH}$") branch_entry="${branch_sha} # HEAD of \"$ONLINE_BRANCH\" as of $(date +%d.%m.%Y)" if [[ -d "${OSA_ROLE_LOCAL}_${repo_name}" ]]; then repo_tmp_path="/tmp/${repo_name}" # Ensure that the temp path doesn't exist [[ -d "repo_tmp_path" ]] && rm -rf "${repo_tmp_path}" # Do a shallow clone of the repo to work with git clone --quiet --depth=5 --branch ${ONLINE_BRANCH} --no-checkout --single-branch ${repo_address} "${repo_tmp_path}" pushd ${repo_tmp_path} > /dev/null git checkout --quiet "${branch_sha}" popd > /dev/null # Update the policy files find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "policy.json" -exec \ cp {} "${OSA_ROLE_LOCAL}_${repo_name}/templates/policy.json.j2" \; # Tweak the paste files find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*[_-]paste.ini" -exec \ sed -i.bak "s|hmac_keys = SECRET_KEY|hmac_keys = {{ ${repo_name}_profiler_hmac_key }}|" {} \; # Update the paste files find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*[_-]paste.ini" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${OSA_ROLE_LOCAL}_${repo_name}/templates/\$(basename \${name}).j2\"" \; # Tweak the rootwrap conf files find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "rootwrap.conf" -exec \ sed -i.bak "s|exec_dirs=|exec_dirs={{ ${repo_name}_bin }},|" {} \; # Update the rootwrap conf files find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "rootwrap.conf" -exec \ cp {} "${OSA_ROLE_LOCAL}_${repo_name}/templates/rootwrap.conf.j2" \; # Update the rootwrap filters find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*.filters" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${OSA_ROLE_LOCAL}_${repo_name}/files/rootwrap.d/\$(basename \${name})\"" \; # Update the yaml files for Ceilometer if [ "${repo_name}" = "ceilometer" ]; then find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*.yaml" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${OSA_ROLE_LOCAL}_${repo_name}/templates/\$(basename \${name}).j2\"" \; fi # Update the yaml files for Heat if [ "${repo_name}" = "heat" ]; then find ${repo_tmp_path}/etc -name "*.yaml" -exec \ bash -c "name=\"{}\"; cp \${name} \"${OSA_ROLE_LOCAL}_${repo_name}/templates/\$(echo \${name} | rev | cut -sd / -f -2 | rev).j2\"" \; fi # Clean up the temporary files [[ -d "repo_tmp_path" ]] && rm -rf "${repo_tmp_path}"# Finally, update the PIP_INSTALL_OPTIONS with the current versions of pip, wheel and setuptools

commit_message:
WIP: Searchlight resource-type registration

This patch is WIP ONLY for now.  It provides a resource-type registration
by which resource types (images, instances, etc.) register their actions
and other features so searchlight can use them.

Change-Id: I7280d03bff1c1164b95591d0e0cff91d342c16a2

legacy 6633 and IANA assigned 6653 ports; only check br-int
configuration for later ODL releases.

Drop wider service checks from amulet test.

commit_message:
Enable Mitaka amulet tests

Disable Juno tests (no longer supported).

Switch Xenial tests to use BE release of ODL, as the default
Helium release is not compatible with Java 8 (which is the
default in 16.04).

Update ovs bridge controller checks to validate against
legacy 6633 and IANA assigned 6653 ports; only check br-int
configuration for later ODL releases.

Drop wider service checks from amulet test.

Re-align with Neutron security group management.

Change-Id: Ic1e92b292c0276232a29695d02096ba1e3275236

commit_message:
Cleanup and archive unmerged specs

Move specs that didn't land in older releases into
an archive folder. Also cleanup example specs in
preparation to push tacker-specs to spec.openstack.org
and fixup tests to ignore old specs and 'archive' dir

Change-Id: I339acea056c95d55e3630f70a6301393cc34035f

deleted_lines: # Swift A distributed object storage system designed to scale from a single machine to thousands of servers. Swift is optimized for multi-tenancy and high concurrency. Swift is ideal for backups, web and mobile content, and any other unstructured data that can grow without bound. Swift provides a simple, REST-based API fully documented at http://docs.openstack.org/. Swift was originally developed as the basis for Rackspace's Cloud Files and was open-sourced in 2010 as part of the OpenStack project. It has since grown to include contributions from many companies and has spawned a thriving ecosystem of 3rd party tools. Swift's contributors are listed in the AUTHORS file. ## Docs To build documentation install sphinx (`pip install sphinx`), run `python setup.py build_sphinx`, and then browse to /doc/build/html/index.html. These docs are auto-generated after every commit and available online at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/. ## For Developers The best place to get started is the ["SAIO - Swift All In One"](http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/development_saio.html). This document will walk you through setting up a development cluster of Swift in a VM. The SAIO environment is ideal for running small-scale tests against swift and trying out new features and bug fixes. You can run unit tests with `.unittests` and functional tests with `.functests`. If you would like to start contributing, check out these [notes](CONTRIBUTING.md) to help you get started. ### Code Organization * bin/: Executable scripts that are the processes run by the deployer * doc/: Documentation * etc/: Sample config files * swift/: Core code * account/: account server * common/: code shared by different modules * middleware/: "standard", officially-supported middleware * ring/: code implementing Swift's ring * container/: container server * obj/: object server * proxy/: proxy server * test/: Unit and functional tests ### Data Flow Swift is a WSGI application and uses eventlet's WSGI server. After the processes are running, the entry point for new requests is the `Application` class in `swift/proxy/server.py`. From there, a controller is chosen, and the request is processed. The proxy may choose to forward the request to a back- end server. For example, the entry point for requests to the object server is the `ObjectController` class in `swift/obj/server.py`. ## For Deployers Deployer docs are also available at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/. A good starting point is at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/deployment_guide.html You can run functional tests against a swift cluster with `.functests`. These functional tests require `/etc/swift/test.conf` to run. A sample config file can be found in this source tree in `test/sample.conf`. ## For Client Apps For client applications, official Python language bindings are provided at http://github.com/openstack/python-swiftclient. Complete API documentation at http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-object-storage/1.0/content/ ---- For more information come hang out in #openstack-swift on freenode. Thanks, The Swift Development Team

subject: Don't require a Content-Length for 204 responses
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-15 17:56:06.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/common/custom_matchers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/1d58653764837711117e32843e104f68c6738579', 'message': "Don't require a Content-Length for 204 responses

A 204 response has no content by definition so there is no need
to require a Content-Length header.

Change-Id: I74c074986ec0bc9f44ba5baf48b0207cd77ebd5f
"}]
commit_message:
Don't require a Content-Length for 204 responses

A 204 response has no content by definition so there is no need
to require a Content-Length header.

Change-Id: I74c074986ec0bc9f44ba5baf48b0207cd77ebd5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/67/306567/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if actual.get('status') != '204': if 'content-length' not in actual: return NonExistentHeader('content-length')
deleted_lines: if 'content-length' not in actual: return NonExistentHeader('content-length')

commit_message:
Copy iPXE ROMs into /tftpboot

Previously we assumed that they're put there by some external process
(eg this is performed by instack-undercloud in TripleO).

Change-Id: I82ecd63e212b41b80adba2e679fb1d0cb81dbde7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ironic refs/changes/90/302390/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if $::osfamily == 'Debian' { $ipxe_dir = '/usr/lib/ipxe' } elsif $::operatingsystem == 'RedHat' { # CentOS does not include all necessary ROMs in OS packages (2016-04-06) $ipxe_dir = '/usr/share/ipxe' } else { $ipxe_dir = undef } if $ipxe_dir != undef { file { '/tftpboot/undionly.kpxe' ensure => 'present', source => "$ipxe_dir/undionly.kpxe" file { '/tftpboot/ipxe.efi' ensure => 'present', source => "$ipxe_dir/ipxe.efi" } } } else { warning("iPXE ROM source location not set, ensure ROMs are copied into /tftpboot")
deleted_lines: $test_ipxe_images_present = true, if $test_ipxe_images_present { exec { 'test BIOS iPXE image present': path => '/tftpboot/undionly.kpxe', command => 'test -f <path>' exec { 'test UEFI iPXE image present': path => '/tftpboot/ipxe.efi', command => 'test -f <path>' } }

subject: Rabbitmq Upgrade restarts container only when image was changed.
revisions:

This fix adds a check of Rabbitmq's image version during the upgrade.

commit_message:
Rabbitmq Upgrade restarts container only when image was changed.

This fix adds a check of Rabbitmq's image version during the upgrade.
The container gets restarted only when the image version is different.

Change-Id: Ie038845c0c8fff1ac51b7cbf21e1b593229c2c0e
Closes-Bug: #1558832
(cherry picked from commit d73ee4a856b84b5d19d7b604f49ce5cbb8d061d4)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/76/306576/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Checking if rabbitmq container needs upgrading kolla_docker: action: "compare_image" common_options: "{{ docker_common_options }}" name: "rabbitmq" image: "{{ rabbitmq_image_full }}" when: inventory_hostname in groups['rabbitmq'] register: rabbitmq_differs when: - rabbitmq_hostname != (gospel_node.stdout | from_json).hostname - rabbitmq_differs['result'] when: - rabbitmq_hostname == (gospel_node.stdout | from_json).hostname - rabbitmq_differs['result'] when: - rabbitmq_hostname != (gospel_node.stdout | from_json).hostname - rabbitmq_differs['result']

commit_message:
Not using mox stubs in nova.tests.unit.consoleauth

remove stubs with newly introduced stub_out
function also use mock to replace old mox in consoleauth subfolder.

Part of blueprint remove-mox

Change-Id: Ic0bd6b74b74790cd794fa8b7e235671264c7f0b5

commit_message:
run-wheel.sh: only run wheel for Python projects

tarball JJB macro run wheel, but we have to verify if the project is
whether or not a Python project.

This patch will make possible for Puppet modules to run the tarball
macro without complexity.
We check if it's a Python project if metadata.json file IS NOT present.
Indeed, this file is really Puppet specific.

Change-Id: Id2e307ae53b8ef1bb2be71c8ba3541cadb5ca12b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/98/306398/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # metadata.json is a file present in Puppet modules but not in Python projects. # Based on this information, we'll run wheel only on Python projects. # This conditionnal allows to run tarball JJB macro for both types of projects. if [ ! -r metadata.json ]; then venv=${1:-venv} export UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=$(pwd)/upper-constraints.txt rm -f dist/*.whl tox -e$venv pip install wheel tox -e$venv python setup.py bdist_wheel FILES=dist/*.whl for f in $FILES; do echo -n "SHA1sum for $f: " sha1sum $f | awk '{print $1}' | tee $f.sha1 echo -n "MD5sum for $f: " md5sum $f | awk '{print $1}' | tee $f.md5 done fi
deleted_lines: venv=${1:-venv} export UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=$(pwd)/upper-constraints.txt rm -f dist/*.whl tox -e$venv pip install wheel tox -e$venv python setup.py bdist_wheel FILES=dist/*.whl for f in $FILES; do echo -n "SHA1sum for $f: " sha1sum $f | awk '{print $1}' | tee $f.sha1 echo -n "MD5sum for $f: " md5sum $f | awk '{print $1}' | tee $f.md5 done

commit_message:
add new portal_port option for iscsi module

IPA supported iSCSI portal port customization by 272420 patch.

With this patch, we add new portal_port argument into
agent_client.start_iscsi_target() method to pass iSCSI portal
port to IPA side. And add new configuration into iscsi module as
below:

CONF.iscsi.portal_port

Reference:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/272420/

Change-Id: Ia1515cbd6723a965e362a7dfa0b58077194401f3
Closes-Bug: #1523829
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/88/303888/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: iscsi_opts = [ cfg.PortOpt('iscsi_portal_port', default=3260, help=_('iSCSI portal port.')), ] CONF.register_opts(iscsi_opts, group='iscsi') portal_port = iscsi_options['iscsi_portal_port'] result = agent_client.start_iscsi_target(node, iqn, portal_port) 'iscsi_portal_port': CONF.iscsi.portal_port,

commit_message:
Add Unit Tests for manila_config type

*remove empty line

Change-Id: Id8562dd2743993e6364a657e8e4e0716af148191
Partial-bug: #1440401
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-manila refs/changes/55/304955/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'should require a name' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:manila_config).new({}) }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, 'Title or name must be provided') end it 'should not expect a name with whitespace' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:manila_config).new(:name => 'f oo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should fail when there is no section' do expect { Puppet::Type.type(:manila_config).new(:name => 'foo') }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Parameter name failed/) end it 'should not require a value when ensure is absent' do Puppet::Type.type(:manila_config).new(:name => 'DEFAULT/foo', :ensure => :absent) end it 'should accept a valid value' do @manila_config[:value] = 'bar' expect(@manila_config[:value]).to eq('bar') end it 'should not accept a value with whitespace' do @manila_config[:value] = 'b ar' expect(@manila_config[:value]).to eq('b ar') end it 'should accept valid ensure values' do @manila_config[:ensure] = :present expect(@manila_config[:ensure]).to eq(:present) @manila_config[:ensure] = :absent expect(@manila_config[:ensure]).to eq(:absent) end it 'should not accept invalid ensure values' do expect { @manila_config[:ensure] = :latest }.to raise_error(Puppet::Error, /Invalid value/) end

commit_message:
Switch tests to use rspec-puppet-facts

This change updates the default tests to use rspec-puppet-facts to do
testing with each of the supported operating systems.

Change-Id: I53420e4ad7c143a8b2be932c8f2f9d62b465e792
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-cookiecutter refs/changes/67/305467/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fixing keepalived bug when 2+ backup nodes have the same priority
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-14 15:06:16.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/vars/configs/keepalived_haproxy.yml', 'doc/source/install-guide/configure-haproxy.rst', 'playbooks/haproxy-install.yml', 'releasenotes/notes/keepalived-upgrade-e63a11b7d4dcba20.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/3468bf256576edc4acd364dbbe922ce92a579755', 'message': "Fixing keepalived bug when 2+ backup nodes have the same priority

The issue is present if you're running 2 or more nodes with
a keepalived < 1.2.8. This bumps the version of keepalived role
(installing a more recent version of keepalived by default) AND
edits the keepalived configuration file to avoid having nodes
with the same priority.

This will restart your keepalived service.

Please note this commit is not meant for backporting. The deployer

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/279664/

Bug: #1545066

Change-Id: Ie28d2d3fa8670212c64ecbdf5a87314e7ca0a2d9
(cherry picked from commit 12a3fbafd03ff7272125a7b71e4538dadd252699)
"}]
commit_message:
Fixing keepalived bug when 2+ backup nodes have the same priority

The issue is present if you're running 2 or more nodes with
a keepalived < 1.2.8. This bumps the version of keepalived role
(installing a more recent version of keepalived by default) AND
edits the keepalived configuration file to avoid having nodes
with the same priority.

This will restart your keepalived service.

Please note this commit is not meant for backporting. The deployer
running on mitaka and below should follow the documentation here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/279664/

Bug: #1545066

Change-Id: Ie28d2d3fa8670212c64ecbdf5a87314e7ca0a2d9
(cherry picked from commit 12a3fbafd03ff7272125a7b71e4538dadd252699)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/13/305913/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - There is a new default configuration for keepalived, supporting more than 2 nodes. - In order to make use of the latest stable keepalived version, the variable ``keepalived_use_latest_stable`` must be set to ``True`` issues: - In the latest stable version of keepalived there is a problem with the priority calculation when a deployer has more than five keepalived nodes. The problem causes the whole keepalived cluster to fail to work. To work around this issue it is recommended that deployers limit the number of keepalived nodes to no more than five or that the priority for each node is set as part of the configuration (cf. ``haproxy_keepalived_vars_file`` variable). upgrade: - There is a new default configuration for keepalived. When running the haproxy playbook, the configuration change will cause a keepalived restart unless the deployer has used a custom configuration file. The restart will cause the virtual IP addresses managed by keepalived to be briefly unconfigured, then reconfigured. - A new version of keepalived will be installed on the haproxy nodes if the variable ``keepalived_use_latest_stable`` is set to ``True`` and more than one haproxy node is configured. The update of the package will cause keepalived to restart and therefore will cause the virtual IP addresses managed by keepalived to be briefly unconfigured, then reconfigured.

commit_message:
Add TLS to Kibana Web Interface

Use HAProxy to terminate a TLS connection on port 5601 for the
Kibana dashboard when TLS is enabled for Kolla. x-forwarded-for
and x-forwarded-proto headers are set to give Kibana the info it
needs to write returned URLs.

Change-Id: I03a2dd3a8e2513d38281b30bf4bae6449fec0316
Closes-bug: #1566117

commit_message:
Collection of CSS fixes

This ensures all parameter tables are 100% wide, even if they have
only a few items with short descriptions. It makes all the tables the
same width.

This moves the link icon into the gutter for the main content, and
makes it hidden by default (only visible on hover) like in the API
site today.

This makes the link + method name div be ``white-space: nowrap`` to
ensure that when the screen gets narrower the Delete button doesn't
fold up on itself.

Part of bp:api-ref-in-rst

Change-Id: I3892e6c8e3c01956d63a33603ba1bf9146d21161
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/306376/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: } /* Ensure the method buttons and their links don't split lines when the page is narrower */ .operation { /* this moves the link icon into the gutter */ margin-left: -1.25em; margin-right: 1.25em; white-space: nowrap; } /* These make the links only show up on hover */ a.operation-anchor { visibility: hidden; } .operation-grp:hover a.operation-anchor { visibility: visible; } /* All tables for requests should be full width */ .api-detail table.docutils { width: 100%; }

commit_message:
Convert devstack docs jobs to regular format

Devstack used to be using "shocco" to build HTML pages of scripts,
which I think was the reason these jobs were not using the existing
framework.  That is removed with
Ie7f4b265368f1d10a8908d75e11d625b2cc39e7c so I think we can remove any
devstack-specific documentation jobs.

Change-Id: I3a4128f6ee24b295e86d9e13af1e6d0a4d429269

commit_message:
Add TLS to Kibana Web Interface

Use HAProxy to terminate a TLS connection on port 5601 for the
Kibana dashboard when TLS is enabled for Kolla. x-forwarded-for
and x-forwarded-proto headers are set to give Kibana the info it
needs to write returned URLs.

Change-Id: I03a2dd3a8e2513d38281b30bf4bae6449fec0316
Closes-bug: #1566117

commit_message:
Fix missing 'qos' in extension drivers

When qos plugin is defined in 'neutron_plugin_base' it should
also be added to 'extension_drivers' at ml2_conf.ini. If not,
neutron-server will not start, throwing the following error:
"ExtensionDriverNotFound: Extension driver qos required for
service plugin qos not found."

Change-Id: I87839e8c0fb0db27b89538d10d0573e80235260a
(cherry picked from commit 239f58dd40515f0c6355fbbfbb26a90ca2c25322)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron refs/changes/10/305810/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: extension_drivers = port_security{% if 'qos' in neutron_plugin_base %},qos{% endif %}

commit_message:
Remove stub_compute config options

console use stub_compute to perform easy unit test,
it can use mock to do the test without config option,
so remove it and it's safe because it's only related
to test purpose and no side effect to end user.

Change-Id: If38148e178e50a348810312826b16cbd34ba550b

commit_message:
Deprecate managing of rabbitmq resources

We stopped to manage rabbitmq resources from openstack puppet
modules a long time ago, but manila module still contains
rabbitmq class for its managing. This patch deprecates it.

Change-Id: Ica717e76374359f8eb3a4e2f0c06fff48fd05b2d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-manila refs/changes/81/305981/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: warning('manila::rabbitmq class is deprecated and will be removed in next release. Make other plans to configure rabbitmq resources.')

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-15 09:07:26.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/haproxy/templates/haproxy.cfg.j2', 'ansible/roles/kibana/tasks/config.yml', 'ansible/roles/kibana/templates/kibana.json.j2', 'ansible/group_vars/all.yml', 'ansible/roles/kibana/templates/kibana.yml.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/079cbaf865cf5b8eef3bad45824fbc67e4e9c93c', 'message': 'Enable TLS/SSL for Kibana

This uses a proxy bridge to enable Kibana TLS/SSL encryption.  In
this model the initial connection to HaProxy is secured via TLS
for password authentication, so password authenticatoin is not done
over freetext.  After that, HaProxy decrypts the data from the backend
service and re-encrypts it using the TLS connection setup on the
frontend.

Change-Id: I6ab57673436dd11f88dc2958da65cfcc83328569
Closes-Bug: #1566117
'}]
commit_message:
Enable TLS/SSL for Kibana

This uses a proxy bridge to enable Kibana TLS/SSL encryption.  In
this model the initial connection to HaProxy is secured via TLS
for password authentication, so password authenticatoin is not done
over freetext.  After that, HaProxy decrypts the data from the backend
service and re-encrypts it using the TLS connection setup on the
frontend.

Change-Id: I6ab57673436dd11f88dc2958da65cfcc83328569
Closes-Bug: #1566117
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/02/306302/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Stop uploading to job logs to swift

We have some headroom on the logs filesystem and this allows us to go
back to more reliable methods of grabbing logs. Specifically we are not
required to have http access back to the jenkins master from every job
that runs into order to get the console logs then upload them to swift.

Change-Id: Ie8479c224b2fd3c3efca4e1bf4157656540eccff

added_lines: from cinder.api.openstack import versioned_method @ddt.data(True, False) def test_experimental_property(self, experimental): request = api_version_request.APIVersionRequest() request.experimental = experimental self.assertEqual(experimental, request.experimental) def test_experimental_property_value_error(self): request = api_version_request.APIVersionRequest() def set_non_boolean(): request.experimental = 'non_bool_value' self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameterValue, set_non_boolean) def test_version_matches_experimental_request(self): experimental_request = api_version_request.APIVersionRequest('2.0') experimental_request.experimental = True non_experimental_request = api_version_request.APIVersionRequest('2.0') experimental_function = versioned_method.VersionedMethod( 'experimental_function', api_version_request.APIVersionRequest('2.0'), api_version_request.APIVersionRequest('2.1'), True, None) non_experimental_function = versioned_method.VersionedMethod( 'non_experimental_function', api_version_request.APIVersionRequest('2.0'), api_version_request.APIVersionRequest('2.1'), False, None) self.assertTrue(experimental_request.matches_versioned_method( experimental_function)) self.assertTrue(experimental_request.matches_versioned_method( non_experimental_function)) self.assertTrue(non_experimental_request.matches_versioned_method( non_experimental_function)) self.assertFalse(non_experimental_request.matches_versioned_method( experimental_function))

commit_message:
WIP: Try to get service name in logs

When running the cinder-volume service with multiple backends,
it is very difficult to corrolate which log messages are posted
by which backend. This patch is an attempt to inject the service
name into the context so it is available for logging.

Change-Id: I94279dd4224aef72d4babaa73c11775665d62c60

commit_message:
Propose policy-based scheduler for Newton

We propose a policy-aware scheduler that allows the Nova
administrator (as well as Nova tenant administrators) to
control placement decisions by writing policy statements
that dictate which VMs or containers can be placed on which
hosts.  The policy-aware scheduler will plug into the
existing scheduler framework, enabling administrators to
choose the scheduler when Nova is deployed.

Change-Id: Ief07aefb0196a9072177cf8146f61cab3f7d8f55
Blueprint: policy-based-platform-aware-scheduler
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/98/297898/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================ Policy-driven, Platform-aware Nova Scheduler ============================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/policy-based-platform-aware-scheduler We propose a policy-aware scheduler that allows the Nova administrator (as well as Nova tenant administrators) to control placement decisions by writing policy statements that dictate which VMs or containers can be placed on which hosts. The policy-aware scheduler will plug into the existing scheduler framework, enabling administrators to choose the scheduler when Nova is deployed. Problem description =================== To customize scheduling decisions in the existing filter scheduler, an administrator configures which filters (and weights) Nova should apply when making decisions. One of the most extensible frameworks ("Host Aggregates") gives the administrator the ability to compare host aggregate metadata using equality. If the pre-built filters and weights are inadequate, the administrator creates new filters and installs them into Nova. The core problem this spec addresses is that those new filters must be written in Python. Asking administrators to write custom Python code leads to a collection of potential security, correctness, and performance problems for Nova, but it also leads to a maintenance problem for administrators: that custom code must be dealt with during upgrades and must be updated whenever the filter scheduler interface or data structures change. Also, in cases where administrators rely on support contracts from their OpenStack providers, writing python code adds possible implications to these support models and increases the support effort. Moreover, as more data becomes available for making scheduling decisions (such as attributes from other sub-systems like network and storage and advanced compute capabilities like crypto HW acceleration [1][2][11]) and as the sophistication of desired scheduling decisions increases (such as joint network and compute awareness for emerging distributed NFV deployments within OpenStack [22]), the likelihood that administrators will want custom scheduling logic increases. The more sophisticated the scheduling decisions users want to make, the more difficult it becomes for Nova developers to anticipate all potential scheduling needs. It should be also noted that Policy-Driven and Platform-Aware scheduling ultimately allows better (re)configurability of the dataplane and compute resources by allowing more fine grained use of platform resources such as hardware acceleration and more targeted NUMA placement for VMs, for different usecases that admins are implementing. Admins now have the ability to change their policies based on the NFV usecase they drive into their network. What we need is a way for administrators to define custom scheduling logic without writing Python code. Ideally, it would be expressive enough to satisfy administrators' needs, natural to use, and pose no security or integrity problems for Nova as a whole. A policy-based platform-aware scheduler satisfies these requirements by using a declarative language that was purpose-built to enable people to express the kind of rules and constraints that appear in scheduling, yet is restrictive enough to give performance, security, and integrity guarantees. Use Cases --------- A policy-based scheduler has several use cases. 1. Extensibility. Recent requests from the Neutron [1][2], Cinder, and OPNFV [19][20] teams ask for a scheduler that makes placement decisions based additional information about candidate hosts such as their proximity to storage and constraints on how networks are configured. Using the filter approach requires developers to anticipate the primitive constraints on compute, networking, and storage that the administrator might want, and write those filters in Python. As the number of external information sources grows, it becomes even more difficult to anticipate which filters will be valuable because of network effects, complicating scheduling decisions based on interactions between the different services. A policy-based scheduler allows an administrator to specify scheduling decisions using whatever data is available, regardless whether that data comes from just Nova or it comes from Nova, Neutron, and Cinder. 2. Understandability. The specs for the order-based filter scheduler [7], the externally-pluggable scheduler [8], and the architecture spec [15] point to a general desire for improved usability of the current filters+weights scheduler. A policy-based scheduler helps usability in multiple dimensions. First, the administrator has complete control over the placement decision because she writes the logic that computes the list of candidate hosts for a given request. Nothing is hidden from the administrator, making it more understandable. Second, because the policy language has been restricted to be safer than Python, we can build tools that do deep analysis and answer questions such as are there hosts that can never be used to schedule any VM? Third, instead of scheduling requests being codified as a potentially large collection of key/value pairs, external systems can provide human-readable policy statements that encode scheduling preferences, which makes the more exotic use cases surrounding SR-IOV, HW acceleration for crypto, and NUMA awareness [17] more natural. 3. Monitoring. After VMs have been scheduled, administrators sometimes want to continue monitoring and refining the placement decision [9]. If for example, the network load, storage availability, or CPU utilization change, some VMs may need to be migrated to new hosts. It is important to have a single representation of the scheduling logic that can be used for both initial placement and subsequent monitoring. Without a single representation, the mechanisms that are doing placement and monitoring can end up fighting each other. A policy-based scheduler allows the administrator to write the scheduling logic using declarative policy statements that can be used both for scheduling (find all those hosts a new VM is permitted on) and monitoring (based on the latest update of data, enumerate all the VMs that are no longer permitted on the hosts they are deployed to.) Proposed Change ================== We propose creating a new scheduler that plugs into the existing scheduling framework where administrators provide policy that describes exactly what the scheduling decision for any request should be. Conceptually, on every request the policy-based scheduler combines the request, data from the Nova database, and the administrator-supplied policy to compute the hosts that are permitted for the request. ARCHITECTURE. |-----------------------| | Nova | | Conductor | |-----------------------| | ^ | | | | Input: Output: Scheduling Candidate Request Hosts | | | | | | v | |-----------------------| | Policy | | Scheduler | |-----------------------| | | | | |---------| |--------------| | Nova DB | | Policy Store | |---------| |--------------| Policy language: YAML and Datalog ------------------------------------------------- A policy is a collection of statements in a declarative language that define the permitted hosts for any given request and any given (Nova) data. For the policy language we have chosen YAML, to make it as easy to use for administrators as possible. Under the hood, this YAML language is translated to the variant of Datalog used by OpenStack Congress [10]. Datalog is a well- known, declarative language that has been the subject of research and development for over 30 years, so while the YAML policy language presented below is new, its foundations are mature and well-understood. Besides ensuring that the YAML language we introduce has well-understood foundations, using Datalog as a backend provides an additional benefit. Administrators who want to write custom policies that YAML cannot express can write those policies directly in Datalog. This approach gives administrators the best of both worlds: an easy-to-understand YAML language for the common case, and an expressive Datalog language for cases requiring a high degree of customization. Below we briefly introduce both the YAML and the Datalog policy languages. YAML policies ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A YAML policy is conceptually similar to the filters and weights approach. The administrator defines a policy with hard constraints and soft constraints. The hard constraints give conditions on the hosts that must be true; the soft constraints assign weights to each host. The hosts that are selected by the policy are those that satisfy all the hard constraints and have the maximum weight. An administrator can also specify parameters for a policy, which are values that the user provides when requesting a new host. The example below illustrates all of these features (and Appendix A includes a fuller example). parameters: availability_zone: type: String label: availability zone number description: Name of the availability zone server should be hosted on. affinity : type : String label : Affinity description: Affinity Group Id ram : type : integer label : RAM description: Minimum RAM size required by server instance in GB. hard_constraints: ram_constraint: operation_type : min value : { get_param : ram } affinity_constraint: operation_type : equals value : { get_param : affinity } availability_zone_constraint: operation_type : equals value : { get_param : availability_zone } soft_constraints: ram_factor: operation_type : multiplication value : { get_param : ram-weight} Datalog Policies ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ YAML can be used for many common cases, but it is limited to only those keywords such as ram_constraint, affinity_constraint, availability_zone_constraint that we as developers have built into the language. When those built-in keywords are inadequate, the scheduler provides the administrator the option to utilize the more powerful Datalog language for writing policies. Datalog is more expressive than YAML in that it gives finer grain control of scheduling decisions to the policy writer, and lets the policy writer combine information from multiple sources of data (such as from different tables from the databases of Nova, Neutron, and Cinder). Just like a YAML policy, a Datalog policy takes request parameters and returns a list of hosts that satisfy the request. In the example below we show how affinity and anti-affinity constraints can be codified in Datalog using data from the Nova database and the user request. The list of hosts that the scheduler returns are defined by main(). The first rule defines main() in terms of eliminated_host(), max_host_score(), and weight(). There is nothing special about eliminated_host, max_host_score, or weight; they can be appropriately chosen by the administrator. Conceptually, the rule says that a host is a candidate for the request if there is no reason to eliminate it, and it has the highest weight among hosts that are not eliminated. main(host) :- nova:host(host), not eliminated_host(host), max_host_score(host, max), The next two statements define eliminated_host(). One way for a host to be eliminated is when the same_hosts field contains a VM that IS NOT DEPLOYED on the given host. eliminated_host(host) :- nova:host(host), request:same_hosts(vm), not nova:deployed(vm, host) A second way for a host to be eliminated is when the different_hosts field contains a VM that IS DEPLOYED on the given host. eliminated_host(host) :- nova:host(host), request:different_hosts(vm), nova:deployed(vm, host) The next line computes the host with the highest score. max_host_score(host, max(score)) :- weight(host, score) The next rule assigns weights so that machines with the greatest amount of free RAM is preferred, assuming at most 256GB of RAM per host. weight(host, ram_weight) :- request:ram(requested_ram), nova:host_ram(host, actual_ram), ram_weight = actual - requested_ram / 256 A few things to note: * Datalog has all the usual boolean operators: AND (multiple conditions in a single rule), OR (multiple rules for eliminated_host), NOT. * Datalog has limited, implicit iteration. For example, the rule that defines eliminated_host implicitly loops over all the compute hosts in the Nova table and checks if they are prohibited. Even with this simple example, it is hopefully clear that the administrator has more power to control the scheduling decision with Datalog, but that the YAML version is a better choice when that additional power is unnecessary. Request for Feedback -------------------- There are a number of implementation decisions that we would like feedback from the community on before proceeding with this spec. 1. Policy CRUD. Mechanically, how does the administrator create or update the policy? Some options: (i) Edit a file on the same host the scheduler is running. (ii) Make (new) CRUD API calls into Nova. (iii) Edit the policy on Congress and have the scheduler update its copy by contacting Congress (either by pull or push). [Especially valuable would be suggestions about what we should do initially and what we should do longer-term.] 2. Policy language. Comments and suggestions on our YAML policy language would be much appreciated. 3. Data ingestion. The policy based scheduler needs data to evaluate policy, some of which is available in the Nova database, and some of which belongs to external OpenStack components such as Neutron and Cinder. The ingestion of data from external OpenStack components is the subject of separate specs [4][5][6], which we plan to leverage and contribute to. In the short term we will focus on just policies that rely on the Nova database, and in the long term we will allow policies that rely on data from external OpenStack components as well. We see several options for making the data contained in the Nova database available to the policy-based scheduler: 3a. Use the existing host-state data structure created within the filter- scheduler. The benefit to this approach is that we use a well-known method of ingesting data. The drawback is that we would need to copy the host-state data structure into the data structures needed by the YAML policy engine, yielding 2 copies of the SQL data instead of just 1. 3b. Fill the data structures needed by the YAML policy engine directly from the Nova database. This would be more performant than option (1) since it would avoid an extra copy of data. 3c. A longer-term option would be compiling the policy into an SQL query and evaluating it directly over Novas database. The benefit to this option would be that we would need 0 copies of the SQL data. 3d. Leverage the nova object store API to access data inside the Nova database. Alternatives ------------ Alternatives and their tradeoffs were covered in depth earlier. Data model impact ----------------- Depends on community feedback as to where policy is stored and how the administrator modifies it. * If policy is stored in the Nova database, we would need a new table for storing policies. Will provide details depending on community feedback. * If stored on disk, there is no change to the database schema, but care must be taken to ensure the policy file is stored on the same node as the scheduler. * If retrieved from Congress, there is no impact to the data model at all. REST API impact --------------- Again this depends on community feedback. The only potential API impact would be adding CRUD for policy. We will provide more details if the community decides API changes are required. Security impact --------------- The only potential security impact is the longer-term option for compiling the policy into a SQL query. The compilation would be done in a way that ensured the compilation of the SQL query contains no user-supplied data, and hence SQL injection would not be an issue. In particular, it is only the administrator-supplied policy that would be compiled into SQL; the user-supplied request data would be (temporarily) made available to the database via the usual ORM facilities. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- This spec focuses on cloud administration policies that are used by the scheduler in its placement decision-making process. In the long run, tenant administrators can also be allowed to set policies controlling the placement of their applications. Performance Impact ------------------ Evaluating the policy at runtime could in the worst case require a significant amount of computation. To give the administrator control over the worst-case computational cost of policy evaluation, the policy-scheduler will have a configuration option that allows the administrator to pick a tradeoff between the expressiveness of the policy language and its computational complexity. That configuration option will enable the administrator to choose high performance at the cost of less expressiveness or to choose increased expressiveness at the cost of lower performance. Another longer-term option for performance improvement is pre-compiling the policy into an SQL query. Other deployer impact --------------------- We plan to use the existing methodology for configuring Nova to use a scheduler other than the default. In the long-run, we plan to make it easy for an administrator to migrate from the filter scheduler to the policy-scheduler by including in the YAML language all the same filters and weights as in the existing filter-based scheduler. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Arun Yerra: Arun_Yerra@DELL.com Other contributors: Tim Hinrichs (OpenStack Congress PTL): timothy.l.hinrichs@gmail.com Ramki Krishnan: Ramki_Krishnan@dell.com Ruby Krishnaswamy: ruby.krishnaswamy@orange.com Joseph Gasparakis: joseph.gasparakis@intel.com Dilip Krishnaswamy: dilikris@in.ibm.com Work Items ---------- We will fill in further details once we get community feedback around implementation choices. The following tasks are necessary in all cases. 1. Extract Datalog engine from OpenStack Congress into library 2. Provide YAML front-end to the Datalog engine, and incorporate into library 3. Ingest Nova database data into policy engine 4. Build scheduler to invoke policy engine as appropriate Dependencies ============ This blueprint aims to address some of the usability and extensibility issues pointed out by existing Nova specs [7] [8]. It will leverage the ongoing work within Nova aimed at making data from Neutron/Cinder available for scheduling decisions [4], once that work is completed. [11] relates to the affinity and anti-affinity policies given in the example. The change proposed here does not require any of the specs mentioned above to be completed. This change will amplify the benefits of those specs. Testing ======= We will fill this in once we get community feedback around implementation choices. Please discuss the important scenarios needed to test here, as well as specific edge cases we should be ensuring work correctly. For each scenario please specify if this requires specialized hardware, a full openstack environment, or can be simulated inside the Nova tree. Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation for the Admin Guide will be expanded to describe the configuration of the policy-based scheduler, and how to write policies. Related efforts =============== 1. Solver scheduler [12] provides optimization based resource placement in Nova. The policy-based approach complements optimizing schedulers by allowing dynamic selection of constraints, weights and optimization targets. Similarly, the ETSI NFV PoC on Constraint-based Placement and Scheduling for NFV/Cloud Systems [16] can leverage this effort.. 2. OPNFV Copper project [18] centered around NFV infrastructure deployment policies can leverage this effort. 3. IETF NFVRG efforts around policy [15], [22] can leverage this effort as a practical implementation of the proposed use cases and architectural framework. 4. This blueprint can leverage OpenStack Congress [21] for the implementation. 5. As the implementation progresses, we plan to demonstrate the functionality of the new scheduler in projects such as OpenStack Tacker [13]], Open Source MANO [14], AT&T ECOMP [3] and OpenStack Congress [21]. References ========== [1] Neutron spec: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/liberty/qos-api-extension.html [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/263898/ [3] AT&T control, orchestration, and policy http://about.att.com/content/dam/snrdocs/ecomp.pdf [4] Spec for enhancing Nova to extensibly handle external data sources http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/resource-providers.html [5] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/253187/8/specs/mitaka/approved/generic-resource-pools.rst [6] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/resource-classes.html [7] Ordered filter-scheduler spec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/256323/6/specs/backlog/approved/ordered-filter-scheduler.rst [8] Externally pluggable scheduler: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/252395/2/specs/backlog/approved/externally-pluggable-scheduler.rst [9] Continuous VM placement monitoring during Vancouver OpenStack summit: https://www.openstack.org/summit/vancouver-2015/summit-videos/presentation/helping-telcos-go-green-and-save-opex-via-policy [10] Congress Datalog: https://congress.readthedocs.org/en/latest/policy.html [11] OpenStack* Enhanced Platform Awareness: https://networkbuilders.intel.com/docs/OpenStack_EPA.pdf [12] Solver Scheduler: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/solver-scheduler [13] OpenStack Tacker: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Tacker [14] Open Source MANO: https://osm.etsi.org/ [15] Policy Architecture and Framework for NFV Infrastructures: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-irtf-nfvrg-nfv-policy-arch/ [16] Constraint-based Placement and Scheduling for NFV/Cloud Systems: http://nfvwiki.etsi.org/index.php?title=Constraint_based_Placement_and_Scheduling_for_NFV/Cloud_Systems [17] Who is in control?  especially of virtual instance lifecycle and resource allocation: Keynote at SDN & OpenFlow World Congress 2015 [18] OPNFV Copper Project: http://artifacts.opnfv.org/copper/docs/design/index.html [19] Several enhancements to OpenStack scheduler within the OPNFV project: https://wiki.opnfv.org/resource_scheduler [20] Network bandwidth accounting enhancement to OpenStack scheduler within the OPNFV project: https://etherpad.opnfv.org/p/rs_bp_network_bandwidth_filter [21] OpenStack Congress: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Congress [22] NFVIaaS Architectural Framework for Policy Based Resource Placement and Scheduling: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-krishnan-nfvrg-policy-based-rm-nfviaas/ History ======= Optional section for Mitaka intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. commit_message:
ensure mysql defaults file is sourced

The mysql initscript that comes with mariadb-10.0 does not source the
/etc/default/mysql file, meaning that the MYSQLD_STARTUP_TIMEOUT that
we set in there is being ignored.  This has the effect of causing some
nodes to timeout their startup too early, interrupting the initial SST,
and causing the cluster join to fail.

This commit adds a line to the initscript to ensure that we are
sourcing /etc/default/mysql correctly.

Closes-Bug: #1569446
Co-Authored-By: Jimmy McCrory <jimmy.mccrory@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I6af1cc660c2bbc2a49707cfab995659dc0167f2f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/50/306450/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE: (mancdaz) this should not be needed with mariadb-10.1 since its # initscript sources /etc/default/mariadb - name: fix mysql startup timeout lineinfile: dest: /etc/init.d/mysql state: present insertafter: '^export HOME=/etc/mysql/' line: '[ -r /etc/default/mysql ] && . /etc/default/mysql' backup: yes # NOTE: (mancdaz) The target will need to change to /etc/default/mariadb # for mariadb-10.1

commit_message:
Remove VENV before pushing to Zanata

For horizon, we pushed 10+ files to Zanata, since all pot files in the
VENV were pushed as well.

Remove the VENV before we push to the translation server.

Change-Id: I236af881b2fa46bf1f676ebe06513fb27accaf5f

added_lines: # First, delete our VENV, otherwise the Zanata client might push some # extra files. rm -rf $VENV

commit_message:
Rabbitmq Upgrade restarts container only when image was changed.

This fix adds a check of Rabbitmq's image version during the upgrade.
The container gets restarted only when the image version is different.

Change-Id: Ie038845c0c8fff1ac51b7cbf21e1b593229c2c0e
Closes-Bug: #1558832

commit_message:
Reorganize test playbooks

The following changes have been made to reorganize the structure of this
role's test playbooks, bringing them into line with other
OpenStack-Ansible roles:
  - move each playbook to an individual file
  - rename playbooks descriptively
  - define hosts and groups directly in the inventory file
  - include group vars required by containers
  - store extra variables in a single shared test-vars file
  - remove use of the openstack_hosts role
  - include callback plugin for human readable logging of test tasks

Change-Id: I4829e368003f58685cb96b7ee743255d00542187

Some clouds (hi internap) have very difficult to discover internal and
external networks. They defy all of our other logic, but we have
configuation for this purpose. However, we were lettting discovery

Change-Id: I62e34b1f0f32c19acbeccd11bc2ea38a2b119951
'}]
commit_message:
Use configured overrides for internal/external

Some clouds (hi internap) have very difficult to discover internal and
external networks. They defy all of our other logic, but we have
configuation for this purpose. However, we were lettting discovery
override configuration. Boo on us.

Change-Id: I62e34b1f0f32c19acbeccd11bc2ea38a2b119951
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/90/306190/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif ((('router:external' in network 'provider:network_type' in network) and network['name'] not in self._internal_network_names and network['id'] not in self._internal_network_names): network['name'] not in self._external_network_names and network['id'] not in self._external_network_names):
deleted_lines: elif (('router:external' in network 'provider:network_type' in network): 'provider:network_type' not in network):

added_lines: stats = {"errors": 0, "failures": 0, "successes": 0} self.stats["failures"] += len(test.failures) self.stats["errors"] += 1 def addSuccess(self, test): """Duplicates parent class addSuccess functionality. :param test: The test that was run :type test: :class:`syntribos.tests.base.BaseTestCase` """ super(IssueTestResult, self).addSuccess(test) self.stats["successes"] += 1
deleted_lines: aggregated_failures = {} pruned_failures = [] for issue in test.failures: url = issue.request.url method = issue.request.method if url in self.aggregated_failures: if method in self.aggregated_failures[url]: if issue.test in self.aggregated_failures[url][method]: (self.aggregated_failures[url] [method][issue.test].append(issue)) else: self.aggregated_failures[url][method][issue.test] = [] self.pruned_failures.append((test, [issue.as_dict()])) else: self.aggregated_failures[url][method] = {} else: self.aggregated_failures[url] = {} self.failures = self.pruned_failures

commit_message:
ImpactedParameter names now understand identifiers in bracketed strings

If your request template has a bracketed string, such as: GET
/v2.0/users/{userid:xxxxxxxxxxxxx}, The ImpactedParameter will now report the
"name" parameter as "userid" instead of "userid:xxxxxxxxxxxxx". However, if our
request template looks like: GET /v2.0/users/{xxxxxxxxxxxxx}, The "name"
parameter will still be reported as "xxxxxxxxxxxxx".

Change-Id: I4cb95d064338501b7397a494e780546884a531c2

deleted_lines: for match in re.finditer(r"{[^}]*}", data): yield ( "{0}{1}{2}".format( cls.remove_braces(data[:start]), string, cls.remove_braces(data[stop:])), cls.remove_braces(data[start:stop]) )

commit_message:
networking-midonet: Move coverage job from post to check

This coverage job doesn't seem to take too much longer than
usual py27 job.  So no good reason to have it on post.
On my local environment it was "2895.76s user 150.34s system"
vs "2285.94s user 146.06s system".

Change-Id: I8df628110e051a1b7dfdce774d5549dc68721e25

We are currently using block quotes for license comments, which means
that Sphinx pulls this into every module, which is bad. Hash-prefixed

Implements: blueprint docstring-add-to-framework

commit_message:
Change license from block quotes to '#'s (Sphinx)

We are currently using block quotes for license comments, which means
that Sphinx pulls this into every module, which is bad. Hash-prefixed
comments for licenses seem to be the standard for OpenStack as well.

Change-Id: Iabc60228c1201a960f672e1b0c7ab3c5312c9d8e
Implements: blueprint docstring-add-to-framework

commit_message:
Use proper CentOS repositories for ceph and qemu

CentOS has a virtualization sig and storage sig which produces
udpated ceph and qemu images.  These images are then reused within
the rest of Red Hat packaging.  Install these repositories for
CentOS and make use of them.

This should work for OracleLinux as well.
Still testing centos.

Co-Authored-By: Vikram Hosakote <vhosakot@cisco.com>
Co-Authored-By: Paul Bourke <paul.bourke@oracle.com>

Conflicts:
	docker/base/Dockerfile.j2

Change-Id: Iea21fc4f33bbfdb973cf354d492c372bd3360acb
Closes-Bug: #1566588
(cherry picked from commit e37fa65f4fd729014f12559d36becb5853c46fce)

commit_message:
Remove config module

Remove the config.py module because:
  - config options in lib should wait for RFE bug 1563069
  - set_db_defaults() used only for tests
  - setup_logging() should not be done by lib

Change-Id: Icdcb2b8f98887edff7809a6a6de7f239bdfe2ff9

commit_message:
Update tempest docs re scenario and slow tests

* Waiting should be avoided in api tests
* Scenario tests should cover real world use cases
* Doc the services decorator
* Define slow tests as 5 seconds

Change-Id: Idd486cdfd95b6a187abedc0af2c3766cd6ddc0f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/44/305144/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: v2  test_recordsets.py  test_zones.py There are two groupings of tests here "api" and "scenario". **API tests** should be quick, and simple. Testing as small a surface area of the API as is possible while still getting the job done. Additionally, API tests should avoid waiting for resources to become ACTIVE etc, as this typically pushes test time out significantly, and would only duplicate scenario tests. **Scenario tests** should cover common real world uses cases. For example, creating a zone, waiting for it to become ACTIVE, adding some records, waiting for ACTIVE, querying the DNS servers themselves, and finally deleting the zone and waiting for it to 404.having to run the entire suite. Another type we use is "slow", which should be applied to tests which take on average 5 seconds or more. @test.attr(type='slow') def test_something_else(self): pass @test.services ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The `services` decorator is used to indicate which services are exercised by a given test. The `services` decorator may only be used on scenario tests, and (for now) should not include "dns" itself. For example, given a scenario test that interactions with Designate's Reverse DNS APIs, which in turn talk to Neutron, we would use something like the below: Example: .. code-block:: python class ReverseTest(BaseDnsTest): @test.services('network') def test_reverse_dns_for_fips(self): pass
deleted_lines: waiters.wait_for_zone_status( self.client, zone['id'], 'ACTIVE') LOG.info('Re-Fetch the zone') _, body = self.client.show_zone(zone['id']) having to run the entire suite.

commit_message:
Fix totp test fails randomly

The test_with_multiple_users test would fail if the time happened to
roll over to the next chunk for the totp generator. The fix is to
control the clock in the test to this can't happen.

Change-Id: I2b92a0cc08ba8e36edc87cb76960a46746895458
(cherry picked from commit 3eaea2fdf417a03aeb539cd35ab28f01de5886af)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/66/306466/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import timeutils return totp.generate(timeutils.utcnow_ts(microsecond=True))

commit_message:
Fix explicit waiting if instance has error status

This patches includes:
- don't wait instance launching if instance in error status
- add missed assertTrue to validate notification messages
- check that message is present and is displayed

Change-Id: If731751fa4deabdeebe373748b169ac7ac617f8c
Closes-Bug: #1569941

commit_message:
Fix doc build if git is absent

When building packages if git is absent, then we should not set
html_last_updated_fmt. It can still be set via the -D switch
when building with sphinx-build.

Change-Id: I9f833ed6c9881803702466775895c1ad63d0d21d
Closes-Bug: #1552251
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/29/305029/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import warningstry: html_last_updated_fmt = subprocess.Popen( git_cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE).communicate()[0] except Exception: warnings.warn('Cannot get last updated time from git repository. ' 'Not setting "html_last_updated_fmt".')

commit_message:
move sphinx h3 to '-' instead of '^'

In the sphinx document h3 is supposed to be '-' not '^':

=, for sections
-, for subsections
^, for subsubsections

We have to enforce consistency here because we're processing included
files which all have to agree, otherwise it's a sphinx error.

Part of bp:api-ref-in-rst

Change-Id: Ic6eef5cacb07870f161b04b031e332f2b87aeedc

subject: Return exceptions as JSON
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-05 17:38:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/searchlight/commit/30d13d6ec4d195ba47a84f13a130384066daa667', 'message': "Return exceptions as JSON

Webob doesn't easily allow non-HTML exceptions. This is inspired
(wholesale) from heat, which wraps exceptions and formats them in
middleware. api-paste.ini is changed to include the middleware.

commit_message:
Return exceptions as JSON

Webob doesn't easily allow non-HTML exceptions. This is inspired
(wholesale) from heat, which wraps exceptions and formats them in
middleware. api-paste.ini is changed to include the middleware.

Change-Id: Ie59df27989b5d2d2dd2dd1b1570f9a586cbfe8fe
Closes-Bug: #1469336

commit_message:
Add a few more layout checks

Create three new checks for zuul/layout.yaml:
* Ensure every project has a check job
* Ensure every project has a gate job
* Ensure that no check or gate pipeline mixes noop jobs with real jobs

vinz-webclient did not have any gate jobs defined, so add noop to its
gate pipeline.

Change-Id: I5935cfbb0e99270af22ca144382b35f6a1b08fee

commit_message:
Ensure all units provide ceph-public-addr

radosgw relation was only providing information
when executed by a leader unit. This patch ensures
that the minimum info is provided regardless.

Closes-Bug: 1570823
Change-Id: Ice044350c0c7b30ce65554b2ba5476d537588126

commit_message:
Modify add_bridge_ports(...) to include port up and permisc code

This fixes bug#1570411 where the add_bridge_port(...) function was
modified to include a port type but missed off port up and promisc
features.

Change-Id: I2a304270be97ed1eae5a7ceeb5777514460d8b4f
Closes-Bug: #1570411

commit_message:
ensure mysql defaults file is sourced

The mysql initscript that comes with mariadb-10.0 does not source the
/etc/default/mysql file, meaning that the MYSQLD_STARTUP_TIMEOUT that
we set in there is being ignored.  This has the effect of causing some
nodes to timeout their startup too early, interrupting the initial SST,
and causing the cluster join to fail.

This commit adds a line to the initscript to ensure that we are
sourcing /etc/default/mysql correctly.

Closes-Bug: #1569446
Co-Authored-By: Jimmy McCrory <jimmy.mccrory@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I6af1cc660c2bbc2a49707cfab995659dc0167f2f
(cherry picked from commit b9a7361b28a7acb2dd05ef960cf474dc91486a6a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server refs/changes/40/306440/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE: (mancdaz) this should not be needed with mariadb-10.1 since its # initscript sources /etc/default/mariadb - name: fix mysql startup timeout lineinfile: dest: /etc/init.d/mysql state: present insertafter: '^export HOME=/etc/mysql/' line: '[ -r /etc/default/mysql ] && . /etc/default/mysql' backup: yes # NOTE: (mancdaz) The target will need to change to /etc/default/mariadb # for mariadb-10.1

commit_message:
Adjust tempest cleanup strategy to avoid cascading failures

This commit makes some minor tweaks to how the method resources are
cleaned up after each test run to try and avoid cascading cleanup
failures.

Closes-Bug: 1569544

Change-Id: Ia3ea943a70c62818418263c80893889fc8082c8f

commit_message:
Log when task is not configured properly

Currently we fail silently when a task is not configured properly.
Silent failures make things particularly hard to understand when behaviour
does not match expectations.

Change-Id: Ib4d8f2bdf3299caaf91bd5a99c6a014f87143e4a
Closes-bug: 1532243

commit_message:
Use absolute path for VENV

Translation sync of horizon currently fails with:
/usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/common_translation_update.sh: line 320:
./tmp.iqbhMxlZtW/bin/pip: No such file or directory

Use an absolute path for $VENV so that it works just fine.

Change-Id: I9886f916c8d5377f2882e235bb9d70e2cbbfa0ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/07/306507/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

 computes = ComputeNodeList.get_all_by_host(context, host, use_slave)
 return computes[0]

Closes-bug: #1564921

commit_message:
Reload rebuild_instance ComputeManager method

Commit dc0221d7240326a2d1b467e2a367bebb7e764e61 to nova added a new
scheduled_node parameter to rebuild_instance method. If not
specified (as it happens in case of ironic instance rebuild), the
first ironic node is selected:

 computes = ComputeNodeList.get_all_by_host(context, host, use_slave)
 return computes[0]

After the first rebuild, instance.node is updated to be this first
compute node, which causes subsequent rebuilds to fail.

Closes-bug: #1564921
Depends-On: I2fe6e439135ba6aa4120735d030ced31081ef202
Change-Id: I3b414d6d8d244f9fed0e63342f4e05d24fbea0b8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/11/306011/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def rebuild_instance(self, context, instance, orig_image_ref, image_ref, injected_files, new_pass, orig_sys_metadata, bdms, recreate, on_shared_storage=None, preserve_ephemeral=False, migration=None, scheduled_node=None, limits=None): """Destroy and re-make this instance. We override this method so that Nova does not try to reschedule instance on a different node. This happens if scheduled_node is None. """ super(ClusteredComputeManager, self).rebuild_instance( context, instance, orig_image_ref, image_ref, injected_files, new_pass, orig_sys_metadata, bdms, recreate, on_shared_storage=on_shared_storage, preserve_ephemeral=preserve_ephemeral, migration=migration, scheduled_node=instance.node, limits=limits)

commit_message:
Append existing information during port set

Existing --fixed-ip and --binding-profile information is
currently overwritten when a user executes 'port set', but
actually that data should be appended.
This patch fixes the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1564453
Change-Id: I62500c10ccbbc68167f24e9d4fa49e85345d82c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/05/300305/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'binding:profile' in attrs: attrs['binding:profile'].update(getattr(obj, 'binding:profile')) if 'fixed_ips' in attrs and obj.fixed_ips: # To check that obj.fixed_ips is not {} attrs['fixed_ips'].extend(obj.fixed_ips)

commit_message:
Add external network options to osc network set

The following patch adds the options "--external" & "--internal"
and the suboptions to "external": "--default" & "--no-default",
to "osc network set" CLI to provide the user an option to set
a network as an external network or remove the setting.

commit_message:
Fix stack deleting problem in magnum stacks

In magnumclient/exceptions.py exceptions are imported
from magnumclient.common.apiclient so exception class
is not the same as expected in heat/engine/clients/os/magnum.py

Closes-Bug: #1570781
Change-Id: Ie60a735470b9adc38675b613950e6480e28136ab

subject: make query for fixed bugs match more bugs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-15 09:36:50.000000000', 'files': ['release.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/release-tools/commit/52ef90cc0597cc6b593d8f633a87775dfa359031', 'message': 'make query for fixed bugs match more bugs

The git log is queried for the exact string "Closes-Bug:". It doesn't
take into account a lower case of that phrase or the usage of a space.

This change will match for :
* "Closes-Bug:"
* "Closes Bug:"
* "closes-bug:"
* "closes bug:"

For example, for Nova version 12.0.0..13.0.0 this means:
* before the change: 253 matches
* after the change: 302 matches

Change-Id: I0d5c411fc81d7c69a2ae326a13cb0de788da0787
'}]
commit_message:
make query for fixed bugs match more bugs

The git log is queried for the exact string "Closes-Bug:". It doesn't
take into account a lower case of that phrase or the usage of a space.

This change will match for :
* "Closes-Bug:"
* "Closes Bug:"
* "closes-bug:"
* "closes bug:"

For example, for Nova version 12.0.0..13.0.0 this means:
* before the change: 253 matches
* after the change: 302 matches

Change-Id: I0d5c411fc81d7c69a2ae326a13cb0de788da0787
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/18/306318/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BUGS=$(git log $PREVIOUS..$VERSION | egrep -i "Closes(.| )Bug:" | egrep -o "[0-9]+")

commit_message:
Fix D401 PEP8 violation.

Currently tox ignores D401 (401: First line should be in imperative mood).
This change removes it and make keystoneauth docstring compliantwith it.

Change-Id: I136cf810f47c4c19f29216907a63f226930b5082
Partial-Bug: 1570049

commit_message:
Fix retrieving VHDX block size

We need the VHDX block size when retrieving the maximum internal
size of a VHDX for a specific file size.

The issue is that we rely on the virtdisk.dll API to give us this
value, while for fixed size images, the block size will always be
reported as 0.

This can easily be avoided by reintroducing the method which actually
parses the image file in order to retrieve the VHDX block size.

Closes-Bug: #1569451
Change-Id: Id035dbc070566817a60eed8270e39c52d3b54821
(cherry picked from commit a4e6cb7d4a46fe0a875d3427e4fd0ca83ee13ff9)
