commit_message:
Neutron API evolution strategy

This specification discusses, in a very boring and pedant
way, a plan for moving away from extensions as a way to
evolve the API and introduce micro versioning as it has
already been done for Nova and Ironic.

Since, it is very boring, read only if properly caffeinated
(or if you are trying to get asleep).

DocImpact
ApiImpact

Change-Id: I7674147172baec42cf3ee03f13ef4e4255586447
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/60/136760/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Consolidate Neutron extensions ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/consolidate-extensions The goal of this blueprint is to simplify Neutron extensions by redefining the concept of "core" Neutron API. The expected benefits are: * Stopping extensions nonsenses. Several extensions indeed implement features so critical that without them Neutron could not interact with Nova. * Providing a consolidated view of the API. Currently extensions, and in particular "attribute extensions", are causing the API to look different from deployment to deployment. * Simplyfing DB management code. Condensing extensions into core will allow us for squashing together a few DB mixins, such as those for L3 DB management * Paving the way for microversioning; moving away from extensions is indeed a necessary step for introducing API evolution through versioning. Problem Description =================== Currently Neutron defines 26 extensions in the neutron.extensions package, plus a number of plugin-specific extensions in the various plugin packages. Some of these extensions, such as load balancing, or IPSEC VPN, implement additional services which might or might not be part of a Neutron service offering. However, most of the current extensions in reality represent an evolution of the core API defined for the Folsom release. Extension such as 'router' and 'securitygroups' indeed implement some of Neutron's core functionality. The notion that Neutron can be as simple as a service providing bare L2 connectivity is indeed obsolete. Even if the number of available extensions is not overwhelming, this already causes some problems for API consumers. Since the structure of requests and responses can change from deployment to deployment, achieving portable applications which make use of the Neutron API is rather difficult. By "portable" here we mean applications which can be used against different OpenStack API providers. Moreover, API evolution through extension is an approach that tends to become confusing and hard to maintain in the long term, even if results very practical in the short term as it avoids versioning. However, situations in which one needs to extend an extensions are indicative of a condition where this approach is already being abused. Proposed Change =============== Many of the extensions currently defined will become part of the core Neutron API. The implementation section lists the extensions which will become part of the enlarged core API. This section only discusses impact on plugins and ML2 drivers. Impact for end users and deployers is discussed in the appropriate section. The aim of this change is not to force plugin and drivers to implement things that nowadays are considered optional. Therefore, plugin and driver maintainers will not need to ensure they implement all the extensions which will be moved into core - even if it would be really nice if they did. However someneutron extensions, such as security groups or L3, must be available in every deployment. On the other hand other extensions, such as "external gateway modes" or "dvr" represent features which might or might not be enabled in a given deployment. Plugins and drivers won't be required to implement these optional features, altough the relevant attributes will be part of the core API. From a plugin maintainer perspective this will imply that: * Only a handful of the current extensions will stay as such and will need to be declared in the "supported extensions" list. * Features which a plugin might optionally support will be listed in a "supported features" list. This will include things like dvr, external gateway modes, or dhcp options. * There will be no change to the authorization model for what currently are "extended" attributes. This will be addressed with a separate blueprint. * The mixin approach, albeit another candidate for overhauling, will not be touched as part of this blueprint. However, some mixins might be "coalesced" as a part of this process. This will have no impact on plugin and drivers, beyond probably changing the name of the mixin the plugin implements * Out of tree plugins might be negatively impacted by this change. For them the advise is to get in touch with Neutron developers on the mailing list to work towards a smooth transition. The changes proposed with this specification are actually only the first step towards API micro-versioning, which has already been approved for Nova_. Once the API is consolidated into "core" and "service extensions", the next step will be to introduce a versioning strategy for all of them and defining rules for ensuring backward compatibility. However, considering other work items targeting the management layer schedule for the same release cycle, such as the switch to Pecan_, it is safer to stage the introduction of a new API evolution strategy, as realistically it might not be possible to complete the work in the Kilo release cycle. Finally, while this plan is implemented it is also likely that new extensions will be proposed and approved for the Kilo release cycle. Approving new extensions might not be the sanest thing to do if there is a consensus on moving away from extensions as a strategy for evolving the API. To this aim: * Extensions proposing an additional, optional, service which does not alter any resource of the core API might be approved. * Extension enabling optional features on existing resources, and exposing them through the API should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. These extensions, if approved, will become part of the core API. Approval criteria are out of scope for this specification * No change will be made to plugin specific extensions, even when they are attribute extensions, mostly for preventing the scope of this specification from becoming too large. In a subsequent iteration plugin specific attribute extensions will become plugin specific features. Note: the proposed change does not affect at all the current extension loading mechanism. The Pecan_ switch activity might however have a non negligible impact on it. Additional note: This proposal does not discuss the impact of this change on RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP, since the Pecan_ switch work item is going to change the way in which API resources are defined. Data Model Impact ----------------- We do not expect any change in the Neutron data model. REST API Impact --------------- This change will introduce a new URI for retrieving enabled features. In other words this will be the URI to retrieve the list of optional feature which were previously availabe under the 'extensions' URI. A feature item will have the following structure: +------------+-------+---------+---------+------------+-------------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +============+=======+=========+=========+============+===================+ |name |string |RO, all |N/A |string |short name | | | | | | | | +------------+-------+---------+---------+------------+-------------------+ |description |string |RO, all |'' |N/A |a relatively | | | | | | |short description | | | | | | |of what this | | | | | | |feature does | +------------+-------+---------+---------+------------+-------------------+ |enabled |boolean|RO, all |N/A |true/false |True if the feature| | | | | | |is enable in the | | | | | | |current deployment | +------------+-------+---------+---------+------------+-------------------+ The /extensions URI will still be available, and it will list those extensions which are orthogonal to the neutron core API (eg: load balancing) It is also important to note that this change will also change the structure of all the resources for which an 'attribute extension' is being moved into the core API. So far if the deployment did not support a given extension, the attribute was not present at all. This caused a resource to look different according to which extensions were enabled. With this change, resources will always have the same shape, but attributes for optional features, such as 'distributed' in the 'router' resource, will be set to a 'null' or 'N/A' value in responses if the feature is disabled; on the other hand if they're specified in requests, and the corresponding feature is disabled, a 501 error code will be returned. This approach is preferrable over blindly ignoring attributes for disabled features. Security Impact --------------- The proposed change does not change the way in which APIs are consumed nor it changes the way in which APIs are dispatched to the plugins. We therefore do not expect this change to have any security impact. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- The API change will be reflected into the CLI. It is important to note that applications relying on querying the 'extensions' URI for feature discovery, including Nova, might be affected by this change. In this case a transitory solution for the Kilo release cycle might be devised, or critical consumers (such as Nova) might be appropriately patched. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- With this change the core API, and therefore the set of mandatory features that every Neutron deployment must expose, will change. Even if there should not be any deployment which does not provide capabilities such as security groups or floating IPs, it is really difficult to make any assertion about how deployers run OpenStack components. For this reason while this change will introduce a "kill switch" that will terminate the service at startup if the mandatory features cannot be made available, this switch will be made optional with a configuration variable. Developer Impact ---------------- The impact for plugin maintainers has already been discussed in the "Proposed Change" section. No further impact is expected. Community Impact ---------------- This change might impact teams which are proposing to introduce new API extensions for the Kilo release cycle. It might also concern community members whose opinion is actually that extensions are the best way to evolve the API. Alternatives ------------ This section discusses alternatives under the assumption that there is consensus about the fact that extensions are not anymore a viable way of evolving the API. A simple alternative approach is to no do anything, but simply document which extensions should be considered part of the core API. However, as there is no way to actually enforce a different API core, this will just increase the chances that actual deployments of the Neutron service provide an API which diverges from the documentation. Another possible alternative is to only a first iteration including into the core the minimal set of extensions which are required for Neutron to work smoothly with Nova. This list will include the l3 extension, the security group one, and possibly a few others. The advantage of this alternative is too have a smoother transition process. However, since the extension approach would still be the way to evolve the Neutron API, it would not fulfill the goal of paving the way for introducing an approach based on API versioning. Implementation ============== The list below discusses which extensions will be made part of the core Neutron API: * agent Admin extension for managing agents Fold into core, mandatory * allowedaddresspairs Relax anti spoof rules on ports fold into core, optional feature * dhcpagentscheduler schedule networks on dhcp agents fold into core, mandatory * dvr Dsitributed virtual router fold into core, optional feature * external_net router:external attribute fold into core, mandatory * extra_dhcp_opt custom dhcp options on ports fold into core, optional feature * extraroute router static routes fold into core, mandatory * firewall edge firewal keep as extension * flavor specific to meta plugin make 3rd party specific, it should not even be here * l3 routers and floating ips fold into core, mandatory * l3_ext_gw_mode control ability of doing SNAT at the gateway fold into core, optional feature * l3_ext_ha_mode create HA router fold into core, optional feature * l3agentscheduler schedule routers on l3 agents fold into core, mandatory * lbaas_agentscheduler schedule vips on lb agents keep as extension * loadbalancer load balancing keep as extension * metering label based bandwidth metering fold into core, optional feature (^) * multiprovidernet like provider, but with multiple bindings fold into core, optional feature * portbindings admin extension for exchanging info and capabilities about ports fold into core, mandatory * portsecurity enable/disable antispoof capabities on a port or network fold into core, optional feature (^^) * providernet provider networks fold into core, optional feature (^^^) * quotasv2 quota management fold into core, mandatory * routedserviceinsertion attach services to routers consider removal or make it plugin specific * routerservicetype specifies which type of router should be implemented consider removal or make it plugin specific * security groups control access to ports fold into core, mandatory * service type select driver for adv services keep as extension * vpnaas IPSEC VPN keep as extension ^ this is a service plugin but conceptually the functionality makes sense as part of the core neutron API ^^ pending progress on the relevant ML2 blueprint. Otherwise it will become plugin specific ^^^ there should be no difference in the new core between provider and multiprovider Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: salvatore-orlando Other contributors: <your naam here> Work Items ---------- * Introduce 'features' URI * Make chosen extensions part of the core API * Revisit DB mixin and coalesce where possible (eg: external gw modes) Dependencies ============ Ideally this change should depend on the Pecan switch. Implementing this blueprint with the current WSGI framework will just mean that we'll have to do the work again once the switch to Pecan occurs. Testing ======= This specification does not change the testing surface, if not for the addition of the 'features' URI for which appropriate unit and API tests will be provided. Tempest however can query neutron extensions to determine which tests should or should not be executed. This mechanisms will need to be tweaked to handle extensions or features, as discussed on the "Other end user impact" section. Tempest Tests ------------- No new tests Functional Tests ---------------- Tests for validating "kill switch" might be introduced. API Tests --------- Tests for covering the 'features' URI Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Significant changes in the API reference documentation. Finally most of the extension appendix will go away. The need for these changes should actually seen as something good. Developer Documentation ----------------------- We would need to document the introduction of the supported_features variable. Trouble is that our developer documentation is so poor that at the moment there is not even a place where this can be stated. References ========== .. _Nova: API micro versioning specification (approved) http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/kilo/approved/api-microversions.html .. _Pecan: Neutron WSGI framework replacement with Pecan (link tbd)

commit_message:
Keep setting backend_host to 'hostgroup' for rbd backends

There are backwards incompatible patches [1][2] in puppet-cinder which break
upgrade scenarios, but at this point they made it to liberty and mitaka,
so workaround in t-h-t is easier than revert

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/209412/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/231068/

Change-Id: Ic82258bf0893ebd4e595e5df73ffbc4c6443f9e8
Closes-Bug: #1570265
(cherry picked from commit 2b15978ba0ef9843345db18aabb2f999d4535381)

commit_message:
Adapt tests for new re-deployment logic

Deployment logic was changed in [1] to start deployment
tasks even if there are no changes to be deployed.

This patch updates functional tests accordingly.

1. I4a6f5f37161e4290050ec4926cf029cd7af566e4

Change-Id: Id8813314f5f8f47a100cbf0975ab60a488164839
Partial-bug: #1565885
(cherry picked from commit 446b8874241657b4715094fc0b8d75f6cfc36deb)

commit_message:
Enable CouchDB replication in Trove

One of the key features of CouchDB is it's ability to replicate a
single database from a source to a target system. Although CouchDB
is a supported datastore in Trove, the replication feature hasn't
been implemented. This spec describes how we can implement CouchDB
replication in Trove.

Change-Id: I1daf2dd6fddab82b0cf007f410d4ce4c68d69571
Implements: blueprint couchdb-replication
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/37/255437/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/template.rst .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None Note: This comment may be removed if desired, however the license notice above should remain. ============================ CouchDB Replication ============================ One of the main features of CouchDB is its replication capability. It provides a way for CouchDB to synchronize documents in a source database with the destination database. It is a one-shot operation which means that the user specifies the source database and the target database (which can be on the same instance/server or different CouchDB instances/servers). CouchDB replication can be configured in different ways so that it is continuous or bi-directional. This spec gives an overview of CouchDB replication and what all changes that needs to be made to enable this feature in Trove. Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/name-of-blueprint Problem Description =================== Even though CouchDB is a supported datastore in Trove, CouchDB replication hasn't been implemented in Trove. This spec addresses how this feature can be implemented in Trove. Proposed Change =============== The basic CouchDB replication is a one shot replication process where the documents in the source database and target database are synchronized. User can trigger replication by specifying the source and target databases. The databases can be on the same server or different servers. An example of a request for replicating database 'db1' from a local server to a remote server on x.x.x.x server would be: curl -X POST -d '{"source":"db1","target":"http://x.x.x.x:5984:db1"}' http://localhost:5984/_replicate CouchDB provides the capability to enable bi-directional(master-master) continuous replication. User can trigger replication both ways(from source->target and target->source) by initiating two separate replication request with the source and target switched. User can also enable continuous replication by setting the parameter, 'continuous' to true. For example: curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:5984/_replicate -d '{"source":"db"," target":"db-replica", "continuous":true}' -H "Content-Type: application/json" CREATE REPLICAS ------------------ The way CouchDB replication works is slightly different from how it works for other datastores for which Trove has implemented replication. For example, replication in CouchDB works at a database level. When user triggers a replication request, they do it to synchronize the documents on a single database between the source and target. Hence, when we create a new replica, we will have to trigger bi-directional continuous replication for each database on the source instance with every replica. NOTE: CouchDB provides an administration console called Futon through which users can create new databases. Once we have created a CouchDB replication set through Trove, new databases created this way(using Futon) cannot be included in the existing replication pattern. Users will have to manually trigger replication for these databases instead. CouchDB does not have officially support any failover mechanism in cases of replication failure. Hence in this release we will not be implementing the eject_replica_set API. DETACH REPLICA ---------------- To detach a replica from a replication set, we will first have to go to the source replica and cancel all existing replications with the replica that we want to detach. PROMOTE TO REPLICA SOURCE -------------------------- To promote a replica to a source/master, we will first have to cancel all existing replications on the current master. Replications on all databases then have to be triggered from the new master to the other replicas including the old master. Configuration ------------- The following configuration parameters needs to be added to the CouchDB configuration group: - replication_strategy - replication_namespace Database -------- None Public API ---------- None Public API Security ------------------- None Python API ---------- None CLI (python-troveclient) ------------------------ None Internal API ------------ None Guest Agent ----------- The following files will need to be added to the guest agent, where the corresponding implementation will reside: .. code-block:: bash guestagent/strategies/replication/experimental/couchdb_incremental.py The following existing files will be updated: .. code-block:: bash guestagent/datastore/experimental/couchdb/manager.py guestagent/datastore/experimental/couchdb/service.py guestagent/datastore/experimental/couchdb/system.py Alternatives ------------ As mentioned above, CouchDB replication works only on a per database level. Based on the conversations I have had with the CouchDB folks, the new clustering API will provide copies of all databases among different instances. (In CouchDB 2.0, it will maintain 3 copies of all databases - we can configure the number of copies/instances up and down). The above mentioned method works best if nodes are located close together. Otherwise a replication based system is recommended. Since CouchDB doesn't support manual failover for replication, there is no obvious way to select a node to be a new master(to implement eject_replica_source). Each CouchDB database consist of one or more documents and each document has a revision id associated with it. One way to find out the next master node would be to compare the revision id of any random document between the different nodes and pick the one with the highest revision id. Another way could be to pick the node that responds back first. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Mariam John (mariamj@us.ibm.com) Milestones ---------- Mitaka Work Items ---------- - Create a new replication strategy for CouchDB (this includes creating the new class couchdb_incremental.py and all the code changes to the existing guestagent files under guestagent/datastore/experimental/couchdb) - Implement API calls for detach_replica and promote_to_replica_source - Write unit and integration tests Upgrade Implications ==================== None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add a new CouchDB helper class to the existing integration-test framework to test CouchDB replication. Documentation Impact ==================== The datastore documentation should be updated to reflect the enabled feature. References ========== .. [1] CouchDB Replication: http://guide.couchdb.org/draft/replication.html Appendix ======== None

commit_message:
Install qemu-image from backports repo

qemu-image has been installed from testing to fix issues when
qemu-img can't convert image:
qemu-img: error writing zeroes at sector 0: Invalid argument

The issue has been fixed in qemu 2.2.0-rc2, reference [0].

Which has been added to debian backports.

This patch fixes issue with building coreos image, when qemu-utils
can't be installed from testing due to dependency problems.

Reference:
[0] http://git.qemu-project.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commitdiff;h=f3a9cfddae
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1389728

Change-Id: Ie62a88e1d012aba1392b19c18137529c4c3ebf31
Related-Bug: #1490086
Closes-bug: #1570090
Closes-Bug: #1569835
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/48/305148/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Add 'backports' for qemu-utils RUN echo 'deb http://httpredir.debian.org/debian jessie-backports main' > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/backports.list proxy.sh apt-get --only-upgrade -t jessie-backports install -y qemu-utils
deleted_lines: # Add 'testing' for qemu-utils RUN echo 'APT::Default-Release "jessie";' > /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/10default && \ sed -e 's/jessie/testing/g' /etc/apt/sources.list > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/testing.list proxy.sh apt-get --only-upgrade -t testing install -y qemu-utils

This change conditionally includes the "scsi_dh" module which
is no longer availabe when using the 4.4 kernel.

commit_message:
Remove setting of heat engine workers

The setting has been added to the puppet manifest [1] and now setting
it here makes the deployment break. So we need to remove it from here
and add it to t-h-t.

[1] I69565c13b732ef74531a516aac8a368597411856

Change-Id: I53a4333ca16df516294c733f85546c0b0a6a0b88

commit_message:
Support the LibreSwan driver in Red Hat platforms

Currently, the libreswan package is supported by puppet-neutron as
part of the openswan driver. However, there is a specific libreswan
driver, which is required when using it (see
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1444017 for details).

Adding support for the LibreSwan driver in puppet-neutron, only for
Red Hat platforms as it does not seem to be supported in Debian/Ubuntu.

Change-Id: I9628e485d301734f9d739c1d03d6da9f7887c61d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/71/273471/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $libreswan_package = 'libreswan' $libreswan_package = false

commit_message:
Ensure mcollective is purged

When mcollective started by the system before cloud-init starts
to reconfigure it subsequent 'service mcollective start' does
effectively nothing leaving mcollective service running with
default config.
The best solution would be to fix cloudinit so that it would
restart mcollective after its config is changed rather than
just start it.
Another solution would be to stop mcollective service before
cloudinit starts to change its config. This solution is almost
impossible to implement - exact time must be chosen.
So, the only solution left is to brutally remove mcollective
package so that it wouldn't start and cloudinit installs
it later.

Change-Id: Id9f10b3b07eb59b21a79b799532121897164f80f
Closes-Bug: #1455489
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-agent refs/changes/79/306279/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # ensure mcollective is purged before cloudinit installs and configures it bootcmd: {% if mcollective.enable == 1 %} - apt-get purge mcollective {% endif %}

added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ Migration to Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) ============================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/support-ubuntu-xenial-xerus Problem description =================== * At the moment Fuel provisions Ubuntu 14.04 (Trusty) as a Host OS, but Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) is coming. * Systemd is a new system and service manager (Upstart is obsolete in Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) and is not to be used any more). * Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) uses Ruby 2.3 by default. Fuel Puppet Providers was designed to work with ruby 1.9 currently used in Ubuntu 14.04 (Trusty). * There are backported system packages from Ubuntu 15.04 or 16.04 (Xenial Xerus), which should be updated to currently shipped with Ubuntu 16.04 to minimize such custom system packages as much as possible. Proposed change =============== - Adapt MOS specific initialization scripts to systemd service manager. - Adapt Puppet's Manifests for Ruby 2.3 - Minimize the number of customized packages required by MOS. - Build MOS specific packages for Ubuntu 16.04 (OpenStack Components and MOS related such as Ceph) Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- Due to significant difference between Ubuntu 14.04 (Trusty) and Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) Cloud Operators won't be able to upgrade already installed clouds to Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus). Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) will be offered as option only for new cloud installations. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployment Engineers as well as System Test will require to use export OPENSTACK_RELEASE="Newton on Ubuntu 16.04.1" Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Albert Syriy <asyriy@mirantis.com> Dmitriy Teselkin <dteselkin@mirantis.com> Ivan Suzdal <isuzdal@mirantis.com> QA assignee: Other contributors: mos-linux mos-packaging fuel-library Work Items ---------- * MOS specific initializing system scripts should be updated for systemd. * Adapt Puppet Ruby providers for Ruby 2.3 * Build MOS Packages for Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) * List of DKMS kernel modules shipped with Ubuntu 14.04 (Trusty) shall be reviewed for Ubuntu 16.04 (Xenial Xerus) Dependencies ============ * OpenStack Patching Process Testing ======= * ISO with Ubuntu 16.04 passes all BVT & Swarm system tests * All main clusters configurations can be successfully deployed * All additional components like Sahara, Ceilometer, Zabbix are to be deployed Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
[CI] Move cinder scenarios to cinder job from neutron_unstable

We have separated non voting cinder job that should test all cinder
plugins. Previously it was in neutron_unstalbe job that was used
for all unstable scenarios, so they won't block the gates.

Change-Id: I7329190031d265002b7e286cee1dcb462d94125e

commit_message:
Translate properties before update

This adds the translation rule call to properties before update, so that
we can remove resource code that refers to deprecated properties. The
new ones are used everywhere with the expectation that the translation
occurred.

Change-Id: Ibdf91ae711f82de5c60896f2452e2872bb3dc9cb
Closes-Bug: #1518676
(cherry picked from commit 003df61ae026174d27b2c44a63527ab93ccc4ac1)

commit_message:
Add support for CouchDB Replication

This implementation includes a strategy for bi-directional replication
for CouchDB. The following replication related commands have been
implemented for CouchDB:
- create (with replica_of and replica_count arguments)
- detach-replica
- promote-to-replica-source

Change-Id: Ic2406d90b3ddc4dd287d68d0bbac3a9d093cc6b2
Implements: blueprint couchdb-replication

[arch-design] Update capacity planning and scaling chapter

Consolidate capacity planning and scaling content from current
guide to the updated arch-guide

Change-Id: I2520954a3b2a67337445615d982263513872b1f5
Closes-Bug: #1548179
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/25/303925/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Public or private cloud or a hybrid cloud, and associated SLA requirementsCapacity planning for a multi-site cloud ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ An OpenStack cloud can be designed in a variety of ways to handle individual application needs. A multi-site deployment has additional challenges compared to single site installations. When determining capacity options be sure to take into account not just the technical issues, but also the economic or operational issues that might arise from specific decisions. Inter-site link capacity describes the capabilities of the connectivity between the different OpenStack sites. This includes parameters such as bandwidth, latency, whether or not a link is dedicated, and any business policies applied to the connection. The capability and number of the links between sites determine what kind of options are available for deployment. For example, if two sites have a pair of high-bandwidth links available between them, it may be wise to configure a separate storage replication network between the two sites to support a single Swift endpoint and a shared Object Storage capability between them. An example of this technique, as well as a configuration walk-through, is available at http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/replication_network.html#dedicated-replication-network. Another option in this scenario is to build a dedicated set of tenant private networks across the secondary link, using overlay networks with a third party mapping the site overlays to each other. The capacity requirements of the links between sites is driven by application behavior. If the link latency is too high, certain applications that use a large number of small packets, for example RPC calls, may encounter issues communicating with each other or operating properly. OpenStack may also encounter similar types of issues. To mitigate this, Identity service call timeouts can be tuned to prevent issues authenticating against a central Identity service. Another network capacity consideration for a multi-site deployment is the amount and performance of overlay networks available for tenant networks. If using shared tenant networks across zones, it is imperative that an external overlay manager or controller be used to map these overlays together. It is necessary to ensure the amount of possible IDs between the zones are identical. .. note:: As of the Kilo release, OpenStack Networking was not capable of managing tunnel IDs across installations. So if one site runs out of IDs, but another does not, that tenant's network is unable to reach the other site. The ability for a region to grow depends on scaling out the number of available compute nodes. However, it may be necessary to grow cells in an individual region, depending on the size of your cluster and the ratio of virtual machines per hypervisor. A third form of capacity comes in the multi-region-capable components of OpenStack. Centralized Object Storage is capable of serving objects through a single namespace across multiple regions. Since this works by accessing the object store through swift proxy, it is possible to overload the proxies. There are two options available to mitigate this issue: * Deploy a large number of swift proxies. The drawback is that the proxies are not load-balanced and a large file request could continually hit the same proxy. * Add a caching HTTP proxy and load balancer in front of the swift proxies. Since swift objects are returned to the requester via HTTP, this load balancer would alleviate the load required on the swift proxies. Capacity planning for a compute-focused cloud ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Adding extra capacity to an compute-focused cloud is a horizontally scaling process. We recommend using similar CPUs when adding extra nodes to the environment. This reduces the chance of breaking live-migration features if they are present. Scaling out hypervisor hosts also has a direct effect on network and other data center resources. We recommend you factor in this increase when reaching rack capacity or when requiring extra network switches. Changing the internal components of a Compute host to account for increases in demand is a process known as vertical scaling. Swapping a CPU for one with more cores, or increasing the memory in a server, can help add extra capacity for running applications. Another option is to assess the average workloads and increase the number of instances that can run within the compute environment by adjusting the overcommit ratio. .. note:: It is important to remember that changing the CPU overcommit ratio can have a detrimental effect and cause a potential increase in a noisy neighbor. The added risk of increasing the overcommit ratio is that more instances fail when a compute host fails. We do not recommend that you increase the CPU overcommit ratio in compute-focused OpenStack design architecture, as it can increase the potential for noisy neighbor issues. Capacity planning for a hybrid cloud ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ One of the primary reasons many organizations use a hybrid cloud is to increase capacity without making large capital investments. Capacity and the placement of workloads are key design considerations for hybrid clouds. The long-term capacity plan for these designs must incorporate growth over time to prevent permanent consumption of more expensive external clouds. To avoid this scenario, account for future applications capacity requirements and plan growth appropriately. It is difficult to predict the amount of load a particular application might incur if the number of users fluctuates, or the application experiences an unexpected increase in use. It is possible to define application requirements in terms of vCPU, RAM, bandwidth, or other resources and plan appropriately. However, other clouds might not use the same meter or even the same oversubscription rates. Oversubscription is a method to emulate more capacity than may physically be present. For example, a physical hypervisor node with 32 GB RAM may host 24 instances, each provisioned with 2 GB RAM. As long as all 24 instances do not concurrently use 2 full gigabytes, this arrangement works well. However, some hosts take oversubscription to extremes and, as a result, performance can be inconsistent. If at all possible, determine what the oversubscription rates of each host are and plan capacity accordingly. their own network, power, and cooling infrastructure. This will give tenants.. TODO Add information on control plane API services and horizon.

No existing control plane sub-chapters in the current guide.

commit_message:
Ensure mcollective is purged

When mcollective started by the system before cloud-init starts
to reconfigure it subsequent 'service mcollective start' does
effectively nothing leaving mcollective service running with
default config.
The best solution would be to fix cloudinit so that it would
restart mcollective after its config is changed rather than
just start it.
Another solution would be to stop mcollective service before
cloudinit starts to change its config. This solution is almost
impossible to implement - exact time must be chosen.
So, the only solution left is to brutally remove mcollective
package so that it wouldn't start and cloudinit installs
it later.

Change-Id: Iba5dd2c022ed6185a16649994a60f1bd417f0f2e
Closes-Bug: #1455489
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-agent refs/changes/75/306275/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # ensure mcollective is purged before cloudinit installs and configures it - apt-get purge mcollective
deleted_lines: # ensure mcollective is stopped before overriding its config and starting it over - service mcollective stop

commit_message:
Switch gate-neutron-dsvm-api to be invoked via tempest plugin framework

Neutron was amongst one of the earliest projects that promoted the
idea of colocating more advanced tests within the project's source
repo itself. The job gate-neutron-dsvm-api was created out of the
tempest backbone when no plugin/tempest-lib were a thing. Things
have matured since, therefore it is time to update some of the
plumbing underpinning this job so that we can start using some of
the latest cool stuff that Tempest has to offer.

The switch must be made conditional to branches since the it only
makes sense from Newton onward.

Depends-on: Ia233aa162746845f6ae08a8157dcd242dcd58eab
Change-Id: If5f7ea82c45494953452f728fabb7403d0b6e14e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/21/304321/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export DEVSTACK_GATE_EXERCISES=0 # NOTE(armax): this condition should be revised every time each of the branches below are dropped. # Prior to Newton, the API tempest tests are invoked explicitly and thus we need the following variables # set. From Newton onward, everything is taken care of by the Tempest plugin framework if [ "$ZUUL_BRANCH" == "stable/kilo" -o "$ZUUL_BRANCH" == "stable/liberty" -o "$ZUUL_BRANCH" == "stable/mitaka" ] ; then export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_NOTESTS=1 export DEVSTACK_GATE_INSTALL_TESTONLY=1 else export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_ALL_PLUGINS=1 fi
deleted_lines: export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_NOTESTS=1 export DEVSTACK_GATE_EXERCISES=0 export DEVSTACK_GATE_INSTALL_TESTONLY=1

commit_message:
Use pybabel instead of python setup.py, enable sync

We use already pybabel for django projects, let's use it also for python
projects. This works around a bug in Babel 2.3.3 with keyword option
parsing and unifies on using pybabel for both python and django.

Also extract the installation of horizon so that it's only done once for
modules that have multiple django modules.

This change uses Babel 2.2.0 now but works with 2.3.3 as well.

Reenable syncing of translation.

Change-Id: Ie220fc9418ae31941d182885e44237dc7fafe10a

added_lines: .. _cli-node-group: Node group management commands ------------------------------ The following table describes node group management commands available in the Fuel CLI. .. list-table:: **Node group management commands** :widths: 10 10 20 :header-rows: 1 * - Description - Command - Example * - List all available node groups. - ``fuel nodegroup`` - List node groups for a specific OpenStack environment: :: fuel --env <env_id> nodegroup * - Create a node group. - ``fuel --env <env_id> nodegroup --create --name "group_name"`` - :: fuel --env <env_id> nodegroup --create --name "group 1" * - Delete a node group. - ``fuel --env <env_id> nodegroup --delete --group <group_id>`` - * - Assign a node to a specific node group. - ``fuel --env <env_id> nodegroup --assign --node <node_id> --group <group_id>`` -

added_lines: .. _file-ref: Fuel configuration files reference ================================== You can modify some of the Fuel settings directly in the corresponding configuration files. .. warning:: For advanced OpenStack users only! Editing the Fuel configuration files may severely damage your OpenStack environment. After you modify a ``yaml`` file, you will get an notification in the Fuel web UI that some settings have been changed and, therefore, some features may become inaccessible in the Fuel web UI. The following table provides descriptions of the Fuel configuration files. +-------------------------------+-------------+------------------------------+ | File | Node | Description | +===============================+=============+==============================+ | :ref:`astute-yaml-master-ref` | Fuel Master | Configuration attributes | | | node | passed to Puppet | +-------------------------------+-------------+------------------------------+ | :ref:`astute-yaml-target-ref` | Fuel Slave | Configuration attributes | | | nodes | passed to Puppet | +-------------------------------+-------------+------------------------------+ | :ref:`engine-yaml-ref` | Fuel Master | Provisioning engine (Cobbler)| | | node | and basic configuration of | | | | the Fuel Slave nodes | +-------------------------------+-------------+------------------------------+ | :ref:`network-1-yaml-ref` | Fuel Master | Network group configuration | | | node | | +-------------------------------+-------------+------------------------------+ | :ref:`openstack-yaml-ref` | Fuel Master | Basic configuration of the | | | node | Fuel Slave nodes | +-------------------------------+-------------+------------------------------+ | :ref:`settings-yaml-ref` | Fuel Master | Fuel settings | | | node | | +-------------------------------+-------------+------------------------------+ This section includes the following topics: .. toctree:: :maxdepth: 1 file-ref/astute-yaml-master.rst file-ref/astute-yaml-target.rst file-ref/engine-yaml.rst file-ref/network-1-yaml.rst file-ref/openstack-yaml.rst file-ref/settings-yaml.rst

commit_message:
Fix circular dependency  of certificate_manager module

The certificate_manager module had a circular dependency that made it
problematic to use for certain versions of the python interpreter.
This was because we were initializing a singleton EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER
that in turn loaded the plugins; The problem was that the plugins
imported certificate_manger themselves and this caused the circular
dependency. So instead of creating that class in the module, I
created a function that should be called instead.

Closes-Bug: #1570356
Change-Id: I9cdb7c3ecc9c275ee561363f6ce13248259f88d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/24/305624/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Singleton to avoid loading the CertificateEventManager plugins more than once _EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER = None new instance of this class use the get_event_plugin_manager function at the module level.def get_event_plugin_manager(): global _EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER if _EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER: return _EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER _EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER = _CertificateEventPluginManager() return _EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER
deleted_lines: new instance of this class use the EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER at the module level.EVENT_PLUGIN_MANAGER = _CertificateEventPluginManager()

commit_message:
NexentaStor5: correct doc page

There was a mistake in my previous commit and NexentaEdge
documentation got in this page instead of NS5 docs.

Change-Id: I9bb641fe02372c3fdc02596777b3d6cca80e09a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/44/304344/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =========================================== NexentaStor 5.x NFS and iSCSI Drivers =========================================== NexentaStor is an Open Source-driven Software-Defined Storage (OpenSDS) platform delivering unified file (NFS and SMB) and block (FC and iSCSI) storage services, runs on industry standard hardware, scales from tens of terabytes to petabyte configurations, and includes all data management functionality by default. NexentaStor 5 brings some new features to the table, such as: * Installation * Profile-based installation for All-SSD or Hybrid appliance * Guided and automated pool creation * Updated license engine * Updated Web-Based User Interface * Chassis Views * Richer set of analytics * Performance monitoring in summary and component dashboards * High-Availability(HA) Cluster displayed as a single appliance * Multi-appliance management * Management * Self-documenting REST API * More intuitive command line interface * File System Enhancements * Added sparing * Persistent L2ARC * Smart compression * Trim/Unmap support * High Performance Replication* * vCenter Plugin * VVOL Support to manage storage policies For NexentaStor user documentation, please visit http://docs.nexenta.com/ Supported Operations* Migrate a volume. * Change volume type. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The NexentaStor appliance must be installed and configured according to the relevant Nexenta documentation. A pool and an enclosing namespace must be created for all iSCSI volumes to be accessed through the volume driver. This should be done as specified in the release-specific NexentaStor documentation. The NexentaStor Appliance iSCSI driver is selected using the normal procedures for one or multiple back-end volume drivers. You must configure these items for each NexentaStor appliance that the iSCSI volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.nexenta.ns5.iscsi.NexentaISCSIDriver # IP address of NexentaStor host (string value) nexenta_host=HOST-IP # Username for NexentaStor Rest (string value) # Password for NexentaStor Rest (string value) # Pool on NexentaStor appliance (string value) nexenta_volume=volume_name # Name of a parent Volume group where cinder created zvols will reside (string value) nexenta_volume_group = iscsi .. note:: nexenta_volume represents a zpool, which is called pool on NS 5.x appliance. It must be pre-created before enabling the driver. Volume group does not need to be pre-created, the driver will create it if does not exist.NFS Driver ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The Nexenta NFS driver allows you to use NexentaStor appliance to store Compute volumes via NFS. Every Compute volume is represented by a single NFS file within a shared directory. While the NFS protocols standardize file access for users, they do not standardize administrative actions such as taking snapshots or replicating file systems. The OpenStack Volume Drivers bring a common interface to these operations. The Nexenta NFS driver implements these standard actions using the ZFS management plane that already is deployed on NexentaStor appliances. The NexentaStor appliance must be installed and configured according to the relevant Nexenta documentation. A single-parent file system must be created for all virtual disk directories supported for OpenStack. This directory must be created and exported on each NexentaStor appliance. For more information on NexentaStor configuration and specs, please visit http://docs.nexenta.com/ You must configure these items for each NexentaStor appliance that the NFS volume driver controls: #. Make the following changes on the volume node ``/etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` file. .. code-block:: ini # Enable Nexenta NFS driver volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.nexenta.ns5.nfs.NexentaNfsDriver # IP address of NexentaStor host (string value) nas_ip=HOST-IP # Port for Rest API (integer value) nexenta_rest_port=8080 # Path to parent filesystem (string value) nas_share_path=POOL/FILESYSTEM # Specify NFS version nas_mount_options=vers=4 Driver Options
deleted_lines: ======================== NexentaEdge iSCSI driver ======================== NexentaEdge is designed from the ground-up to deliver high performance Block and Object storage services and limitless scalability to next generation OpenStack clouds, petabyte scale active archives and Big Data applications. NexentaEdge runs on shared nothing clusters of industry standard Linux servers, and builds on Nexenta IP and patent pending Cloud Copy On Write (CCOW) technology to break new grounds in terms of reliability, functionality and cost efficiencies. For Nexenta user documentation, visit http://docs.nexenta.com. Supported operations~~~~~~~~~~~~ The NexentaEdge cluster must be installed and configured according to the relevant Nexenta documentation. A cluster, tenant, bucket must be pre-created, as well as an iSCSI service on the NexentaEdge gateway node. The NexentaEdge iSCSI driver is selected using the normal procedures for one or multiple back-end volume drivers. You must configure these items for each NexentaEdge cluster that the iSCSI volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.nexenta.nexentaedge.iscsi.NexentaEdgeISCSIDriver # Specify the ip address for Rest API (string value) nexenta_rest_address = MANAGEMENT-NODE-IP # Protocol used for Rest calls (string value, default=htpp) nexenta_rest_protocol = http # Username for NexentaEdge Rest (string value) # Password for NexentaEdge Rest (string value) # Path to bucket containing iSCSI LUNs (string value) nexenta_lun_container = CLUSTER/TENANT/BUCKET # Name of pre-created iSCSI service (string value) nexenta_iscsi_service = SERVICE-NAME # IP address of the gateway node attached to iSCSI service above (string value) nexenta_client_address = GATEWAY-NODE-IP Driver options

commit_message:
Update stable/liberty version to 2.0.2

At some point, we should check if we can delete the version
from stable/liberty too.  But in the interest of enabling
commits to stable/liberty, we'll just bump it for now.

And some fixs for tempest test failures because of other
other project's changes.

Change-Id: I938959db43c1cebf785677839dd8ca3d02f81161

commit_message:
Remove deprecated option 'DEFAULT/verbose'

Option "verbose" from group "DEFAULT" is deprecated from the oslo.log
library. Its value may be silently ignored in the future. If this option
is not set explicitly, there is no such warning.

Furthermore, the default value of verbose is true, so there is no
need to set this value in config files.

Change-Id: If760c42da26aefe49ae52415941e6146bcbccb6a

commit_message:
Ensure mcollective is stopped

When mcollective started by the system before cloud-init starts
to reconfigure it subsequent 'service mcollective start' does
effectively nothing leaving mcollective service running with
default config.
Stopping it before reconfiguration fixes the problem.

Change-Id: Ic9806e4a0a406f701091d3f7cc7ec77c8dbd9029
Closes-Bug: #1455489
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-agent refs/changes/11/305711/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # ensure mcollective is stopped before overriding its config and starting it over bootcmd: {% if mcollective.enable = 1 %} - /usr/sbin/invoke-rc.d mcollective stop {% endif %}

commit_message:
[WIP] datasource pub-sub on new bus

Preliminary implementation of reliable pub-sub over unreliable bus.
Datasource stamps each pub with a sequence number.
Policy engine keeps received updates in a queue and processes them
in order of sequence number.

Out of order updates are reordered.
Duplicate updates are ignored.
Dropped/missing updates are identified.

Testing accomplished by unit tests in test_agnostic as well as functional
tests in test_dse and tests/datasources/*

Note this patch is only here for reference and for feedback.
I do not intend to merge this patch.
Instead, Peter Balland and I expect to put this functionality into the new
dse2.DataService class (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/267227/).

Partially implements blueprint: dist-datasources-on-bus

Change-Id: Id511f2fa867ba120440089c8244efdbc1810a9fb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/60/268360/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # init sequence number for reliable pub-sub self.seqNums = {} # initialize seqNum for this dataindex if dataindex not in self.seqNums: self.seqNums[dataindex] = 0 # attach sequence number, don't increase seq # Assumes every change is immediately pub'ed with a # corresponding increase in seq num, guaranteeing this # full table push aligns with the last pub'ed delta # TODO(ekcs): verify this code cannot be executed in between # state change and seq num increment # add synchronization to ensure return {'init': True, 'seqNum': self.seqNums[dataindex], 'data': []} else: return {'init': True, 'seqNum': self.seqNums[dataindex], 'data': data} # increment and attach sequence number, if result not None if result is None: return None else: self.seqNums[dataindex] = self.seqNums[dataindex] + 1 return {'seqNum': self.seqNums[dataindex], 'data': result}
deleted_lines: return [] else: return data return result

commit_message:
Drop root for swift

Updates to ensure commands run in the swift containers
are done as the 'swift' user rather than root.

Change-Id: I8c5a12e24b9940200241dbe09d6bde8f1cc1cf05
Closes-Bug: #1553895
Co-Authored-By: Serguei Bezverkhi <sbezverk@cisco.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/30/306030/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: RUN pip install oslo.rootwrap COPY swift-rootwrap /var/lib/kolla/venv/bin/swift-rootwrap COPY rootwrap.conf /etc/swift/rootwrap.conf RUN chmod 755 /var/lib/kolla/venv/bin/swift-rootwrap \ && chmod 644 /etc/swift/rootwrap.conf \ && sed -i 's|^exec_dirs.*|exec_dirs=/var/lib/kolla/venv/bin,/sbin,/usr/sbin,/bin,/usr/bin,/usr/local/bin,/usr/local/sbin|g' /etc/swift/rootwrap.conf COPY swift_sudoers /etc/sudoers.d/swift_sudoers RUN chmod 750 /etc/sudoers.d \ && chmod 440 /etc/sudoers.d/swift_sudoers RUN usermod -a -G kolla swift
